After a landlide victory in the Bihar Assembly elections, Prime Minister Narendra Modi celebrated the NDA's win with party workers at the BJP headquarters in Delhi and launched an attack on the Mahagathbandhan. Taking a veiled jibe at RJD president Lalu Prasad Yadav and the "jungle raj" during his reign, PM Modi said that the people have quit supporting those who are out on bail. Addressing BJP workers in Delhi, Prime Minister Narendra Modi said that members within the Congress have grown discontented with what he called the "Muslim League Maoist Congress," predicting another split in the party. The Mahagathbandhan's collapse in Bihar stems from deep internal rifts, a divisive projection of Tejashwi Yadav as CM face, lacklustre and poorly coordinated campaigning by Rahul and Priyanka Gandhi, a misfired SIR narrative, and bitter seat-sharing battles that left allies contesting against each other. In his victory speech, the PM hailed the landslide majority as the victory of the developmental politics orchestrated by both Janata Dal (United) chief Nitish Kumar and the Central government. He also took a sharp jibe at the Mahagathbandhan over its abysmal performance in Bihar. Tej Pratap Yadav declared the "end of family rule" in Bihar as he launched an emotional attack on alleged "Jaichands" within the RJD after the party's collapse. Veteran politician and BJP rebel Yashwant Sinha's sarcastic tweet has become an accidental political prophecy in Bihar Assembly elections. Three days before Bihar poll results, he "predicted" an NDA sweep—and the alliance actually crossed 200 seats. The 88-year-old's post has now gone viral. With the NDA's landslide victory, the spotlight is on its bigger constituents, like the BJP, the JDU and the LJP. Amid the spotlight on the bigger parties, NDA constituent Jitan Ram Manjhi-led Hindustani Awam Morcha (HAM) has won five out of the six seats he contested, registering an impressive strike rate. This is why former Bihar CM Manjhi is the NDA's secret superstar. This special report covers the National Democratic Alliance's resounding victory in the Bihar assembly elections, where it secured a massive majority. The broadcast highlights the celebrations within the BJP and its allied parties, attributing the success to the leadership of Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Chief Minister Nitish Kumar. The report notes the significant contributions of allies Chirag Paswan, Jitan Ram Manjhi, and Upendra Kushwaha, and discusses the victory's implications. Prime Minister Narendra Modi stated, 'I heartily congratulate Chief Minister Nitish Kumar ji and our NDA family allies, Chirag Paswan ji, Jeetanram Manji ji and Upendra Khuswaha ji for this resounding victory'. The programme further analyses the BJP's high strike rate and the role of 'mahila' (women) and 'yuva' (youth) voters in delivering this decisive mandate. Rahul Gandhi, along with all the other Mahagathbandhan leaders, took part in a 16-day-long Voter Adhikar Yatra in Bihar, emphasising vote chori as the central claim. However, that failed to create any impact among the voters of Bihar. The Bihar Assembly Election 2025 is being held in November this year with polling taking place in two phases on 6th and 11th November. Results for the Bihar Assembly polls will be declared on November 14. To check the complete schedule, click here. For the latest news, announcements, candidate lists, and election analyses related to the Bihar elections, stay tuned to indiatoday.in.

cleaned_text: The Bihar Assembly Election 2025 will be held in two phases on November 6 and 11 and the counting of votes will be done on November 14. A total of 121 seats will go to polls in the first phase of Bihar elections and the remaining 122 will vote in the second phase on November 11. The term of the 243-member Bihar Assembly will end on November 22. If you want the latest updates related to the Bihar election, stay connected with indiatoday.in. To find information about any Bihar assembly constituency, either search via the box below or click on its name from the list. No Record Found... The Bihar Assembly (Vidhan Sabha) has a total of 243 seats. Public representatives are elected directly. Bihar will go to polls in two phases on November 6 and 11. In the first phase, polling will be held for 121 seats, while the remaining 122 constituencies will vote in the second phase. The 2025 Assembly Elections may be conducted in two phases. Counting of votes for Bihar elections will be done on November 14. According to the updated 2025 draft voter list, there are more than 72.4 million (7.24 crore) voters in Bihar. After the Special Intensive Revision (SIR) process, around 6.5 million (65 lakh) names were removed. National Democratic Alliance (NDA): Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), Janata Dal (United) [JDU], Hindustani Awam Morcha (HAM)(S), Lok Janshakti Party (Ram Vilas), Rashtriya Loktantrik Morcha (RLM), etc. Grand Alliance (Mahagathbandhan): Rashtriya Janata Dal (RJD), Indian National Congress, Vikassheel Insaan Party (VIP), CPI (ML) Liberation, Communist Party of India (CPI), Communist Party of India (Marxist) [CPI(M)], etc. The major issues in the Bihar Assembly elections will include employment, education, women empowerment, farmers’ issues, law and order, inflation, corruption, caste-based dynamics, and promises of development. SIR, or Special Intensive Revision, is a special process by the Election Commission through which names are added, removed, or corrected in the voter list. It is implemented in Bihar to ensure the voter list is completely updated and impartial. On average, around 800 to 1,200 voters are listed per polling station (booth) in Bihar, though this number may vary depending on the location. You can check the name of the winning candidate in your area on the official website of the Election Commission: https://results.eci.gov.in/. You can also check it on India Today website: https://www.indiatoday.in/elections/assembly/bihar

text: India got lucky, he lives and breathes India: Putin’s big praise for PM Modi
cleaned_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin on Thursday hailed Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s relentless dedication to his work, observing that the Prime Minister “lives and breathes India". In an exclusive interview with India Today, when asked about Prime Minister Narendra Modi, the Russian leader said, “We have very trustworthy and friendly relations. He is a very reliable person. In that sense, I’m speaking very sincerely. India got lucky. He lives and breathes India". Putin said it was a “great pleasure” to speak with the Prime Minister, whom he described as “a person of integrity”. “He is deeply committed to strengthening ties between India and Russia across a wide spectrum, particularly on key areas of economic cooperation, defence, humanitarian engagement, and high-technology development. It is very interesting to meet him,” Putin added. On Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s earlier visit to Moscow, the Russian President recalled that the two leaders had an engaging conversation, “purely like humans.” “He travelled here, and we sat together at my residence. We drank tea the whole evening and discussed a range of topics. We simply had an interesting conversation, purely like humans,” said Vladimir Putin. The Russian President arrived in New Delhi on Thursday for a two-day visit at PM Modi’s invitation, aimed at further strengthening a durable eight-decade-old bilateral partnership that has remained steady despite global geopolitical upheavals. The discussions are expected to focus on cooperation in defence, trade, and technology. In a rare and personal gesture, Modi received Putin at the airport with a warm embrace, where the two leaders shared a hug before heading together in the Prime Minister’s car to his official residence, where the Russian leader was later hosted for a private dinner. Nearly three months earlier, when Modi met Putin in the Chinese city of Tianjin on the sidelines of the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation summit, the Russian President had rode him in his own vehicle, a symbolic gesture that drew global attention, particularly as it came amid strained geopolitical currents and US's tariff pressure on India over New Delhi's relations with Moscow.- EndsPublished By: Priya PareekPublished On: Dec 4, 2025Tune InMust Watch
label: real

cleaned_text: Russian President Putin's interview on India Today Highlights: In a world exclusive, Russian President Vladimir Putin told India Today that Prime Minister Narendra Modi is “not someone who gives in to pressure,” when asked whether the US was arm-twisting India with tariffs. His remarks to India Today Group’s Anjana Om Kashyap and Geeta Mohan came ahead of his two-day visit to India on Thursday. The full interview was shot inside the historic Ekaterina (Catherine) Hall in the Kremlin. In the exclusive interview with India Today TV ahead of his two-day visit to India, Putin was asked whether he believed immortality was achievable - a question triggered by his earlier hot-mic exchange with Chinese President Xi Jinping in Beijing that had gone viral. Putin explained that although life spans can continue to rise through advances in healthcare, true immortality is not possible. He pointed to historic improvements in public health to support his argument, noting how countries such as India have seen dramatic gains in longevity and reductions in infant mortality due to sustained medical efforts. Russian President Vladimir Putin has dismissed the idea of human immortality, saying that while scientific progress can greatly extend life expectancy, “everything has an end; only God is eternal.” When asked whether immortality is achievable, the anchor received a reflective answer from Putin. He said that “everything has an end, only God is eternal,” but added that human life can certainly be extended. “We can extend longevity of life, 100%. I am sure we can,” he said, citing historic improvements in public health. Putin pointed out that 77 years ago, India’s average life expectancy was just 31 years, whereas it is now about 70. He also noted that infant mortality in India has fallen fourfold, underscoring how healthcare advancements drive such progress. Putin said it was a “great pleasure” to speak with the Prime Minister, whom he described as “a person of integrity”. "We have very trustworthy and friendly relations. He is a very reliable person. In that sense, I’m speaking very sincerely. India got lucky. He lives and breathes India," he told India Today TV. When asked about Western newspapers frequently claiming that he wants to restore the old Soviet Union, Putin said he would not explain his position to them because they refuse to listen. He added that they misuse their dominance and monopoly in Western media to justify their aggressive stance toward Russia. Vladimir Putin said that Indian culture is like a fairytale, noting that Russians have enjoyed Indian movies and songs since the USSR era. He described the connection as "heart to heart" and added that Russia will do everything possible to ensure that the interest in Indian culture, built over decades, remains strong. Vladimir Putin said there are several powerful intelligence agencies in the world, including the CIA, Russia’s own services, and Mossad. He added that it is better not to reveal too much information for others to overinterpret, but noted that he is satisfied with how Russia’s intelligence services have evolved. Vladimir Putin described Prime Minister Narendra Modi as a reliable and sincere leader, saying it is very pleasant to talk to someone of such integrity. He noted that Modi is committed to strengthening Russia-India ties in defence, energy, and culture, and added that their conversations are engaging and interesting, "like humans." Vladimir Putin said that Gaza is a complex issue that has remained unresolved for a long time, and any deal should not be rushed. He emphasised that governance should be organised so that control can be transferred to the Palestinian people, reaffirming his support for a Palestinian state. Vladimir Putin said that Russia is looking for additional goods to buy from India, aiming to increase Indian imports and bridge the trade imbalance between the two countries. Vladimir Putin said that India and China are both close friends of his. He described Prime Minister Modi and Xi Jinping as wise leaders, determined to resolve complex issues, and emphasised that Russia does not interfere in any country’s bilateral matters. Vladimir Putin said there is no need to rush, noting that Europe was unprepared for the single currency and faced problems with the euro. He added that Russia is not planning to create a BRICS currency anytime soon. Vladimir Putin said that the world is changing at a rapid pace, with new centres of power emerging and significant transformations underway. He highlighted the Global South in particular, noting that not only India but also Indonesia is on the rise. Putin added that Africa is developing rapidly, and with its young population, the continent will soon aspire to a higher standard of living. Vladimir Putin took a jab at the UK and Germany’s economies, saying most of Europe is staring at a recession and questioning the relevance of the G7, while countries like India rank third globally in economic power. He noted that the G7 is still important, adding that he stopped attending the G8 long ago, and slammed the group’s current actions as “disgusting,” wishing them “good luck.” Vladimir Putin said that Nato poses a threat to both Europe and Russia, undermining Russia’s security and acting as a military alliance against the country. He added that while Ukraine should remain neutral, Russia will continue to protect its interests. Speaking on the endgame, Vladimir Putin said that Russia did not start the war and blamed the West for pushing Ukraine toward conflict. He added that Russian citizens in Donbas were persecuted and emphasised Russia’s deep ties with Kyiv, stating that Russia will completely liberate Donbas. Vladimir Putin said that the United States still buys nuclear fuel from Russia for its own power plants, including uranium for reactors operating in the US. He questioned why India should not have the same privilege, adding that the matter deserves thorough examination and that Russia is ready to discuss it, including with President Trump. "I am absolutely certain that he is sincere about bringing peace to Ukraine and genuinely wants to save lives. But there are also economic and political interests involved," said Putin. "Absolutely no doubt that President Trump had genuine intentions. I am confident that his efforts to bring peace to Ukraine are sincere," Putin said, referring to their Alaska meeting. Vladimir Putin said that neither he nor Prime Minister Modi has ever, despite pressure, used their collaboration to act against anyone. When asked about the US President, he pointed out that Donald Trump has his own agenda, but in their dealings, India and Russia do not cause harm to others, and he wants other countries to take note of this.

cleaned_text: Sanchar Saathi is a digital citizen-safety platform launched by the Department of Telecommunications (DoT) to protect mobile users from fraud, identity misuse, and unauthorized SIM connections. As cases of mobile-related scams, digital impersonation, and telecom-based financial fraud increased across India, the government created Sanchar Saathi as a single, transparent portal where users can check and control all mobile numbers linked to their identity. At its core, Sanchar Saathi offers three major services. The first is TAFCOP (Telecom Analytics for Fraud Management and Consumer Protection), which allows users to see how many SIM cards are issued using their Aadhaar-linked identity. If an unknown number appears, it can be flagged or blocked immediately. This is especially useful in cases where fraudsters obtain SIMs using stolen or forged identity documents. The second major feature is the CEIR (Central Equipment Identity Register). Through this system, anyone who loses their phone whether through theft or misplacement can quickly block the device using its IMEI number. Once reported, the phone becomes unusable on all Indian networks, discouraging mobile theft. If the device is recovered, the portal also allows users to unblock it. The third component involves AI-driven fraud detection, where Sanchar Saathi analyses telecom data to identify suspicious patterns, fake registrations, and SIM misuse. This helps both individuals and telecom operators stay ahead of emerging fraud techniques. Overall, Sanchar Saathi combines transparency, consumer control, and technological vigilance. It empowers citizens, reduces digital vulnerability, and strengthens India’s broader cyber and telecom security ecosystem. text: If US has right to buy fuel from us...: Putin calls out Trump's hypocrisy
cleaned_text: Calling out Donald Trump's hypocrisy, Russian President Vladimir Putin asserted that the US continues to purchase uranium from Russia, key to producing nuclear reactor fuel, while pressuring India to stop energy imports from Moscow. In an exclusive interview with India Today, Putin, who arrived in New Delhi for a two-day visit, emphasised that India should enjoy the same privilege if the US had the right to purchase fuel from Russia. "The US continues to buy nuclear fuel from us for their nuclear power plants. That is also fuel. Energy. This is uranium for nuclear power plants that are functioning in the US," Putin said in the interview ahead of his first visit to India in four years. Russia is the second-largest supplier of enriched uranium to the US, accounting for about 25% of the sales. It is expected to pocket around $1.2 billion from uranium sales to America this year. In 2024, Russia earned approximately $800 million from uranium exports to the US. Framing the issue as one of fairness and strategic balance, Putin said he would discuss the matter with Trump. "If the US has the right to purchase fuel from us, why should India be deprived of such a right? That is a matter to be studied closely, and we are prepared to discuss that and debate that with President Trump," Putin underscored. Catch live updates of his visit to India'ENERGY COOPERATION UNAFFECTED BY SANCTIONS' In the interview, Putin maintained that Russia's energy partnership with India was steady and untouched by Western sanctions. "Our energy cooperation with India remains unaffected by current conditions, fleeting political swings or indeed the tragic events in Ukraine," the Russian strongman asserted. Putin's pointed remarks come at a time when India has been under pressure from Trump to cut back on its imports of Russian oil. The US has claimed that it enables Russia to withstand the pressure of economic sanctions by the West and continue its war against Ukraine, which is set to enter its fourth year. In August, Trump imposed an additional tariff of 25% on India, taking the total levy to 50%, for buying Russian oil. The issue deteriorated ties between the two allies, but has been on an upswing since then. Russia accounts for 35% of India's crude oil imports, compared to 1-2% before the Ukraine war. The Ministry of External Affairs had previously called out the double standards of the US, pointing out that America continued to import uranium hexafluoride for its nuclear industry and palladium for EVs from Moscow.WHAT PUTIN SAID ON MODI, UKRAINE WAR During the 100-minute-long interview, Putin also praised PM Modi's leadership style and his 'Make in India' initiative, calling it a "practical" and powerful force shaping Russia–India cooperation. "PM Modi is a very reliable person. India got lucky. He lives and breathes India," Putin said. On the Ukraine war, Putin stressed that Kyiv started the conflict under the influence of the West, and Moscow would finish it after achieving its goals. - EndsPublished By: Priya PareekPublished On: Dec 4, 2025Tune InMust Watch

text: Russia will finish war when...: What Putin said on Ukraine conflict endgame
cleaned_text: Firing his shots at the West and Ukraine, the Russian President Vladimir Putin, in an exclusive interview with India Today, said that Russia did not start the Ukraine war. Rather, it was Ukraine, under the influence of the West, that involved Russia in the ongoing war. However, Russia will finish the war after achieving its goals. The India Today anchors, Anjana Om Kashyap and Geeta Mohan, then asked Putin what would be considered a victory for him? They also referred to one of his old quotes that mentioned that the country would only submit arms if Ukraine removes troops from several territories claimed by Russia. Answering this, Putin highlighted antagonisms between the two countries. He mentioned that Ukraine has harmed Russian interests by banning the Russian language in several territories and driving people away from temples, churches, and so on. The President noted that Russia is desperate to protect its interests at any cost. "The point is that Russia is determined and will certainly do so to protect its interests, protect its people living there, protect our traditional values, the Russian language, and so on," Putin said to India Today. He further pointed out that Ukraine banned the Russian Orthodox Church and seized many others, and Russia is fighting to reaffirm its position on those territories. In the interview, the President left no stone unturned to foil the conspiracy hatched by the West to start a war against Russia. "The West backed Ukraine and supported the events by orchestrating the coup d'tat. That was the point that triggered the events in Crimea, followed by developments in southeastern Ukraine, in Donbass. However, they never mention it," Putin noted. Putin also said that Russia tried to resolve the matter by taking the path of peace. However, it did not bear fruit, and hence, the country had no other options except to indulge in the war. The interview also touched upon the political turbulence prevailing in the Donbas region, which played a significant part in the Russia-Ukraine war. Putin blamed Ukraine for ushering in violence against the citizens living in that part. "After eight years of relentless violence against those citizens of Donbass, something the West hasn't uttered a word about, we were forced to recognise these republics first, and secondly, provide support," Putin said. "Our special military operation isn't the start of a war, but rather an attempt to end one that the West ignited using Ukrainian nationalists," he further added.- EndsPublished By: Priya PareekPublished On: Dec 4, 2025

text: Everything ends, only God eternal: Putin on viral longevity chat with Xi
cleaned_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin has dismissed the idea of human immortality, saying that while science can significantly extend life expectancy, “everything has an end — only God is eternal.” In an exclusive interview with India Today TV during his two-day visit to India, Putin was asked directly whether he believed immortality was achievable — a question prompted by his earlier hot-mic conversation with Chinese President Xi Jinping in Beijing that went viral worldwide. He was asked: “Do you think immortality is achievable?” Putin replied: “Everything has an end, only God is eternal. We can extend longevity of life, 100%. I am sure we can.” He pointed to historic gains in public health to underline his view. “77 years ago, the average lifespan of a person in India was 31 years, and now it’s about 70. That’s what healthcare does. In India, infant mortality was cut four-fold. These are all the results of healthcare efforts.” He added that advancing technologies, particularly artificial intelligence, would accelerate this progress. “If you use AI in healthcare, and if you use AI to produce drugs, it can have a tremendous effect,” Putin said, while reiterating that human life, ultimately, is finite. “Nevertheless, everything comes to an end.” The unscripted exchange took place on September 3, 2025, in Beijing, as Russian President Vladimir Putin, Chinese President Xi Jinping, and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un walked toward the viewing platform for a military parade marking the 80th anniversary of the end of World War II. The private conversation was inadvertently picked up on a live feed of Chinese state media, quickly circulating worldwide. In the clip, Putin and Xi discussed life extension and human longevity. Putin later confirmed to reporters that he had addressed the topic of extending life expectancy, noting that modern medicine offers hope for a longer active life. The conversation also touched upon controversial areas, including organ transplantation, which remains a sensitive subject in China due to human rights concerns.WHY THE CLIP DREW GLOBAL ATTENTION The video captured imaginations worldwide, offering a rare glimpse into the private reflections of two of the world’s most powerful leaders. Analysts noted the contrast between the leaders’ formal public personas and their personal curiosity about science and technology, including radical life-extension possibilities. Kim Jong Un’s silent presence alongside them added further intrigue to the unexpected moment. The clip gained massive traction as it offered a rare glimpse into an informal, personal conversation between the three leaders.- EndsPublished By: Priyanka KumariPublished On: Dec 4, 2025Tune InMust Watch

text: A handshake and a hug: PM Modi rolls out red carpet for Putin
cleaned_text: In a rare diplomatic gesture, Prime Minister Narendra Modi personally received Russian President Vladimir Putin with a warm hug and handshake as he arrived at Delhi's Palam Airport for a two-day state visit on Thursday evening. The gesture by PM Modi signals the significance New Delhi is attaching to the visit, Putin's first to India since the start of the Russia-Ukraine war. Putin was welcomed with a cultural performance while coming out of the airport before he and PM Modi went on to share another “car moment” with the two leaders travelling together to Lok Kalyan Marg, PM's residence in Delhi. The gesture mirrored their much-talked-about joint ride in Putin’s car during the SCO Summit in Tianjin, China — an image that underscored their personal rapport and became one of the most widely circulated highlights of that meeting. Soon after receiving President Putin, Prime Minister Narendra Modi shared photographs of their meeting and wrote on X, “Delighted to welcome my friend, President Putin, to India. Looking forward to our interactions later this evening and tomorrow. India–Russia friendship is a time-tested one that has greatly benefitted our people.” Delighted to welcome my friend, President Putin to India. Looking forward to our interactions later this evening and tomorrow. India-Russia friendship is a time tested one that has greatly benefitted our people.@KremlinRussia_E pic.twitter.com/L7IORzRfV9— Narendra Modi (@narendramodi) December 4, 2025 PM Modi has extended the rare protocol of personally receiving a foreign leader at the airport only on select occasions. These include:Barack Obama (USA), 2015 — Received in Delhi during his Republic Day visitSheikh Hasina (Bangladesh), 2017 — Welcomed on arrival for a bilateral visitShinzo Abe (Japan), 2017 — Received at Ahmedabad airport ahead of the India–Japan summitDonald J Trump (USA), 2020 — Welcomed at Ahmedabad airport during his India visitMohamed bin Zayed Al Nahyan (UAE), 2024 — Received during the Vibrant Gujarat Global SummitTamim bin Hamad Al Thani (Qatar), 2025 — Welcomed on arrival in New Delhi Putin arrived for a two-day state visit during which several agreements are expected to be signed. The visit coincides with the 25th anniversary of the India-Russia strategic partnership and marks the 23rd annual summit between the two nations. Putin is accompanied by a high-level ministerial delegation, including Defence Minister Andrei Belousov, Finance Minister Anton Siluanov, Agriculture Minister Oksana Lut, Economic Development Minister Maxim Reshetnikov, Health Minister Mikhail Murashko, Interior Minister Vladimir Kolokoltsev and Transport Minister Roman Nikitin.PM TO HOST PUTIN FOR DINNER PM Modi is hosting Putin for a private dinner tonight as both leaders look to reaffirm a partnership that has endured for nearly eight decades despite shifting global alignments and intermittent tensions. Putin’s formal engagements begin on Friday with a meeting with the President of India at Rashtrapati Bhavan, likely around 11 am. He is then expected to visit Rajghat to pay tribute at Mahatma Gandhi’s memorial before proceeding to Hyderabad House, where the core bilateral talks will be held. PM Modi will also host a working lunch for the Russian president around 2 pm, after which structured delegation-level discussions will review ongoing cooperation and identify new areas of partnership. In the evening, President Droupadi Murmu will host a state banquet in Putin’s honour before he departs for Moscow.EXPECTED OUTCOMES FROM THE VISIT Government sources said the visit is poised to significantly deepen economic cooperation, with Putin accompanied by a sizeable delegation of business leaders. India is focusing on reducing its widening trade deficit with Russia by expanding Indian exports — particularly in pharmaceuticals, automobiles, agricultural goods and marine products. Officials said improved access to Russian markets could generate new opportunities for Indian companies, boost employment and support farming incomes. Several agreements and MoUs are expected across shipping, healthcare, fertilisers and connectivity, along with expanded collaboration in mobility partnerships, culture, people-to-people exchanges and scientific research.- EndsPublished By: Ajmal Published On: Dec 4, 2025Tune InMust Watch

text: IndiGo cites pilot shortage for mass flight cancellations; seeks relaxation
cleaned_text: Low-cost flight carrier IndiGo has told the Civil Aviation Ministry that its ongoing wave of cancellations is primarily the result of a pilot shortage compounded by winter-schedule pressures, and has sought partial relaxations in the new Flight Duty Time Limitations (FDTL) norms to stabilise operations. The disclosure came during a review meeting called by Civil Aviation Minister Ram Mohan Naidu after disruptions intensified across the airline’s network, causing chaos across major airports. According to officials, the airline told the ministry that the new FDTL rules, which tighten rest requirements and limit duty hours, have added to resource strain at a time when the carrier is facing a crunch in cockpit crew availability. Naidu also convened a separate meeting with senior officers of the Airport Authority of India (AAI) and directed them to instruct all airport directors to closely monitor the situation and ensure full support for stranded passengers, including assistance at terminals. The minister further asked the DGCA to keep a close watch on airfares during the period of disruptions to prevent undue escalation of ticket prices.SUBMISSIONS MADE BY INDIGO TO MOCA AND DGCA According to ministry sources, IndiGo has formally submitted the following points to the Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA):The airline is facing significant transitional challenges in crew rostering and availability under the Phase-2 FDTL requirements.These issues, compounded by winter operational constraints, have led to the sharp rise in cancellations and delays.To minimise passenger inconvenience while maintaining safety margins, IndiGo has sought operational variations/exemptions from: Para 3.11 (Definition of Night Duty), and Para 6.1.4 (operations encroaching night duty), for A320 operations up to 10 February 2026.IndiGo has assured the DGCA that corrective actions are underway and “normalised and stable operations” will be fully restored by 10 February 2026.The airline has also acknowledged that:The disruptions stemmed from misjudgment and planning gaps in implementing Phase-2 of the FDTL CAR, admitting that actual crew requirements were higher than anticipated.More cancellations are expected for the next 2–3 days as part of schedule stabilisation.From December 8, IndiGo will reduce flight operations to minimise disruption while restoring order. The DGCA has asked IndiGo to submit the specific FDTL relaxations it requires to normalise operations, for regulatory review.DGCA DIRECTIONS TO INDIGO Following the review, the DGCA issued a set of directives to the airline:Roadmap submission: IndiGo must provide a detailed roadmap on crew recruitment aligned with aircraft induction plans.Training and safety planning: The airline must present a plan for crew training, roster restructuring, safety-risk assessments, and mitigation measures ensuring full compliance.Mitigation plan for current disruptions: IndiGo must outline immediate actions to stabilise flights and ensure a progressive reduction in cancellations.Fortnightly progress reports: A comprehensive report every 15 days, detailing operational improvements, crew levels, and roster stability.FDTL relaxation proposal: IndiGo must formally submit the FDTL exemptions required for normalisation, which the DGCA will evaluate. The regulator will continue strict, real-time monitoring of IndiGo’s network performance, restoration efforts, and passenger-handling measures in the coming week.- EndsPublished By: Ajmal Published On: Dec 4, 2025Must Watch
label: real

text: But India is 3rd in purchasing power: Putin shades G7, rules out Russia G8 return
cleaned_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin said the G7 no longer reflects the world’s economic balance, arguing that Europe is slipping into recession while emerging powers such as India now play a far larger role. In an exclusive interview with India Today during his two-day visit to New Delhi, Putin said forums like Brics and the G20 — where India is a core member — have become more relevant than the Western-led G7. Putin, who stressed that he had stopped attending G8 meetings long before the fallout over Ukraine, said the grouping has failed to keep pace with shifts in global economic weight. Asked whether Russia wished to rejoin what was once the G8, he responded with an unequivocal "no", adding that his position on the matter had not changed for years. "At a certain point in time, I simply stopped going to these meetings," he said, noting that the decision pre-dated the Ukraine conflict. He said he effectively stepped back after Russia's 2012 presidential election and returned only occasionally thereafter. He also clarified that his recent conversation with US President Donald Trump’s envoy Steve Witkoff did not involve any formal proposal for Russia to re-enter the group. "There was no proposal," he said.PUTIN CHALLENGES G7's RELEVANCEPutin also questioned the idea that the G7 still represents the world’s leading economic powers. He mocked the label itself, noting that in Russian the letter "G" is associated with the word for "great" or "big", and argued that several major economies are now outside the club. PUTIN CHALLENGES G7's RELEVANCE Putin also questioned the idea that the G7 still represents the world’s leading economic powers. He mocked the label itself, noting that in Russian the letter "G" is associated with the word for "great" or "big", and argued that several major economies are now outside the club. He pointed to India’s position in global rankings by purchasing power, noting that it stands third in the world, ahead of some G7 members. By contrast, he said, countries such as the United Kingdom now rank much lower on that measure. While stressing that G7 states still have "a high-tech economy with a very solid foundation", he said that their position is eroding. He cited recession in Germany "for the third year in a row" and described France as "on the brink of recession", adding that other leading European economies are also under strain. This, he said, was happening "due to the erroneous policy pursued by the authorities of many of these countries". Even so, he stopped short of dismissing the grouping outright. "The G7 is still an important platform. They are working on something, discussing things, making some decisions. Good health to them and all the best," he said.PUTIN BACKS BRICS, SCO AND G20 OVER G7 Putin dismissed the G7 as outdated, pointing instead to Brics, the SCO and the G20 as arenas where Russia is a full participant and where today’s geopolitical balance is more faithfully represented. "Other big associations are coming up, like Brics, the SCO. And the G20 is still active and we are participating in all of these formats," he said, adding that Moscow has "no objections" to working through these platforms. He brushed aside speculation that Western outreach might bring Russia back to a G8 setup, saying there is no compelling reason to return. Putin also took aim at US behaviour, stating Donald Trump criticises India’s energy ties with Moscow even as the United States keeps purchasing Russian uranium. The Russian President also praised PM Modi's leadership, calling the relationship one of deep trust. "We have very trustworthy and friendly relations. He (PM) is a very reliable person...India got lucky. He lives and breathes India," he said. - EndsPublished By: Satyam SinghPublished On: Dec 4, 2025Tune InMust Watch

text: Putin says Trump's tariff stance reflects fear of India's economic rise
cleaned_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin has said that some global powers are uncomfortable with India’s growing strength in world markets, especially as New Delhi continues to buy Russian oil despite Western pressure. In an exclusive interview with India Today, Putin suggested that recent tariff actions by US President Donald Trump and concerns raised by Western nations over India’s Russian oil imports reflect worry about India’s rising economic influence. Putin’s remarks come as the United States and European partners step up enforcement of the Russian oil price cap. They have also issued new warnings to countries, including India, about dealing with sanctioned tankers and intermediaries. Despite these moves, Putin stressed that India–Russia energy ties remain stable. He said the recent pressure was political rather than based on supply and demand. “The issue here is that the pressure you have referred to typically involves employing political instruments to influence normal competition,” Putin said. He added that the energy partnership between the two countries has a long foundation and is not shaped by short-term events. “Our energy cooperation with India remains unaffected by current conditions, fleeting political swings, or indeed the tragic events in Ukraine,” he said. Putin explained that Russian oil companies and Indian refiners had built a strong working relationship well before the Ukraine conflict. He pointed to a major Russian investment in an Indian refinery, calling it one of the largest foreign inflows into the country at more than 20 billion US dollars. This refinery has grown over the years and helped India become a major supplier of refined products to Europe. “It took years to achieve and is in no way connected to the current economic environment,” he said, noting that India’s rise in this space has caused discomfort among some players. “Certain actors clearly dislike India's growing role in international markets owing to its ties with Russia. Consequently, they are seeking means to constrain India's influence for political reasons by imposing artificial obstacles.” Putin also spoke about India–China relations and said both Prime Minister Narendra Modi and President Xi Jinping understand the risks of rising tension. “Both Prime Minister Modi and President Xi Jinping see that some specific tension is rising, and they both try to find solutions to these issues, exerting maximum effort,” he said. He added that Russia views their efforts with respect and does not intend to interfere. “At the same time, Russia does not feel entitled to intervene, because these are your bilateral affairs.”- EndsPublished By: Priya PareekPublished On: Dec 4, 2025Must Watch

text: Our energy cooperation with India remains unaffected, says Vladimir Putin
cleaned_text: Russia’s energy partnership with India remains steady and untouched by the latest Western sanctions, President Vladimir Putin told India Today in an exclusive interview. His comments come at a time when the United States and European partners have tightened enforcement of their price cap on Russian oil and issued fresh cautions to countries, including India, about dealing with sanctioned tankers and intermediaries. Putin, however, played down the impact of these moves and said attempts to influence India’s oil purchases were political in nature rather than grounded in market realities. “The pressure you have referred to typically involves employing political instruments to influence normal competition,” he said. Putting the focus firmly on India, he added that the foundation of the bilateral energy relationship was strong enough to withstand shifting geopolitical winds. “Our energy cooperation with India remains unaffected by current conditions, fleeting political swings or indeed the tragic events in Ukraine,” he said. Putin then highlighted the depth of the hydrocarbons partnership and its long-standing commercial roots. “Regarding hydrocarbons, well before the Ukrainian situation, our business entities had already built a solid and efficient commercial relationship that is based on mutual trust. It is widely known that one of our leading companies acquired an oil refinery in India,” he said, referring to Rosneft’s stake in Nayara Energy. He said that this investment was not minor or symbolic. “This investment represented one of the largest foreign inflows into the Indian economy, totalling 20 billion US dollars. Our company has been continuously expanding the operations of this refinery, working with its partners and operating successfully year after year,” Putin said. According to him, the India–Russia value chain in energy has matured to the point where its impact goes beyond bilateral trade. “As a result, India has become one of the major refined product suppliers to Europe. Not just because it buys our oil at a discount. It took years to achieve and is in no way connected to the economic environment,” he said. Putin also suggested that India’s growing influence in global energy markets is not viewed positively by all. “Certain actors clearly dislike India’s role in international markets, owing to its ties with Russia. Consequently, they are seeking means to constrain India’s influence for political reasons by imposing artificial obstacles,” he said. These comments gain significance because recent US and EU actions have complicated global shipping routes for Russian crude and raised concerns about whether India’s imports will face disruption. Putin made clear that Moscow sees no threat to this partnership and will continue supplying India as usual. He also reiterated that the energy bond between the two countries did not emerge because of sanctions or temporary price advantages. It is, he insisted, the continuation of a commercial relationship that predates the Ukraine conflict and is supported by strategic trust. Putin noted that his personal rapport with Prime Minister Narendra Modi has helped maintain stability in the relationship despite external pressure. He said this trust ensures that cooperation in critical sectors like energy continues without disruption. In India’s context, Russian oil remains crucial for controlling domestic fuel prices and meeting rising demand. Putin’s message signals that, regardless of evolving Western sanctions, Russia expects no interruption in its energy ties with India and views the relationship as long-term, predictable, and built on shared economic interests.- EndsPublished By: Koustav DasPublished On: Dec 4, 2025

text: Couldn't live up to promise: IndiGo CEO apologises over chaos in letter to staff
cleaned_text: IndiGo CEO Pieter Elbers on Thursday apologised after hundreds of flights were cancelled and delayed, leading to massive chaos at airports across cities over the last three days. "We serve close to 380,000 customers a day and want each of them to have a good experience. We could not live up to that promise these past days and we have publicly apologised for that," he said. In the internal email, Elbert further mentioned a set of challenges that impacted the flyer's performance in the last 48 years. He also expressed his gratitude to "all of his colleagues" who were at the operational end, including the pilots, cabin crews, engineers, and several others. In November, the airline witnessed the cancellation of 1,232 flights and severe delays in many flights. Following the drop in performance, the Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA), decided to launch a probe. It asked the airline to cite reasons behind the drastic decline in operations. In response to this, the carrier noted that out of those 1,232 flights, 755 were cancelled because of staff shortages, 92 were cancelled due to the failure in Air Traffic Control (ATC), 258 were cancelled due to airport restrictions, and 127 were cancelled for other reasons. It also sought a two-day period to fix everything and normalise operations. It also said that it initiated calibrated measures. "These measures will remain in place for the next 48 hours and will allow us to normalise our operations and progressively recover our punctuality across the network. text: ‘Modi govt cut off funds, yet…’: How Mamata pitched her performance cardThe BJP dismissed the Trinamool Congress government's report card as lies, deepening the battle-lines for competing narratives in the run-up to West Bengal elections
cleaned_text: On December 2, the corridors of Nabanna in Kolkata briefly felt less like a government office and more like a stage. The spotlight turned towards the ruling Trinamool Congress’s (TMC) decade-and-a-half hold on power as a voice—of National Award-winning singer Iman Chakraborty—rose through the hall in the form of a specially composed panchali, a traditional narrative ballad celebrating West Bengal’s journey under the TMC. The setting was unmistakably administrative, yet the mood carried the cinematic flair of an election season officially underway. It was here, at the state secretariat, that chief minister Mamata Banerjee unveiled ‘Unnayaner Panchali’, her government’s elaborate performance report, as the state prepares for the 2026 assembly polls amidst the Election Commission’s (EC) ongoing Special Intensive Revision (SIR) of electoral rolls. Mamata seized the moment to level a sharp accusation against the Centre, claiming that the BJP-led government was starving Bengal of critical funds. “The central government has withheld our long-pending dues—Rs 1,87,000 crore. When will they pay?” she demanded. “Elections are nearing but development works in Bengal can’t be stopped. Hope, they will release the funds.” Mamata stressed that in spite of what she called political obstruction, the state had continued topping the charts in key welfare infrastructure. “Before the Centre withheld money, West Bengal topped the country in MGNREGA (rural job security), rural housing and village road construction four times in a row,” she said. Even under fiscal strain, she pointed out, her administration had spent Rs 1 lakh crore on Khadya Saathi, benefiting 90 million people, and Rs 1,717 crore on Duare Ration, for 70 million beneficiaries. Mamata projected her governance model as a mix of accelerated economic progress and expansive social protection. “More than 20 million jobs have already been generated in the state during the past 14 years, and an additional 10 million will be created in future,” she said. “Six economic corridors are under construction. We have reduced unemployment by 40 per cent in our state.” Investments worth Rs 2 lakh crore have flowed in since 2011 (when TMC assumed power), she added. Women—the TMC’s most-crucial constituency—remain at the forefront of the narrative. Speaking about Lakshmi Bhandar, Mamata declared: “We are giving a monthly Rs 1,000 to every woman, and Rs 1,200 for those from the SC/ST category. The scheme is lifelong for women. In all, 22.1 million women get the social security benefit.” In a pointed comparison with BJP-ruled Bihar, she said, “They have given a one-time fund of Rs 10,000.” Later, Mamata drew the same arc of achievement in a lengthy post on X, framing Bengal’s political and developmental story as a conscious choice its people made. “Bengal has travelled a long and determined path shaped by the trust of our people and the conviction that development must reach every household, every neighbourhood, every region and every corner of our state,” she wrote. “This is the collective journey of a people who chose progress over prejudice, humanity over hostility, and unity over divisiveness,” she posted, adding that each of her government’s initiative showed the intent that “Bengal’s progress must be broad-based, equitable and sustainable”. Mamata’s post repeated her sharpest grievance: “Despite the Centre withholding Bengal’s dues out of sheer vindictiveness, we have ensured that people’s rights and entitlements are protected.” She listed Kanyashree, Swasthya Saathi, Khadyasaathi, Krishak Bandhu, Duare Sarkar, Karmashree, Banglar Bari among programmes that “safeguard the future of our people”. Even the narrative medium—the modern panchali—was symbolic. “Rooted in Bengal’s soil, language and cultural consciousness, the panchali form has always carried our shared memory and heritage,” she wrote. “In this modern panchali, every verse echoes the transformative journey of our Maa, Mati, Manush.” At Nabanna, Mamata also sought to address the strain on state employees from the SIR process, announcing a compensation of Rs 2 lakh each for the families of some 40 booth-level officers (BLOs) and staff who reportedly died while on duty, including cases of death by suicide. She said 13 others, including three BLOs, who fell critically ill during the SIR exercise would be given Rs 1 lakh each. As Mamata directed officials to accelerate pending works before the model code of conduct for assembly elections kicks in, she also signed off her social media message with a note of gratitude and a political promise: “Your blessings and affection have been our greatest strength and the driving force behind every step of progress. Together, we will continue to write new chapters of growth, equality and hope that reverberate for decades to come.” The BJP countered swiftly. Senior party leader Rahul Sinha alleged Mamata was focused only on “votes, not security” while leader of the Opposition Suvendu Adhikari accused her of “telling lies to the people”. With the battle-lines drawn and both sides ready with competing narratives, the 2026 election show has only just begun. Subscribe to India Today Magazine

cleaned_text: Follow these simple steps to join the competition Choose your class, category, and theme. Submit your performance video (up to 2 minutes) to complete your entry. Your entry will go live on the portal after review and head straight to the jury for semi-final selection. Semi-finalists’ entries will open for public voting. Finalists will be picked based on jury scores and the votes you earn. The finalists from all the categories & class groups will perform live in Delhi on stage. Winners will be solely declared by the verdict of the judges. Pick a category that reflects your style of expression Showcase your command over words and the mastery of your voice. Write your own piece & speak it like only you can. Bring a poem to life with your flair. Whether it's a timeless classic or a contemporary creation, deliver it with passion and emotion. Craft a story born from your imagination. Weave an original narrative rich in creativity and let your words resonate with elegance. Choose a theme that inspires you to create your best performance Exhibit how a simple act of kindness can brighten a life or change the world. Reiterate the value of water to sustain life with your unique vision. Be the voice for a cleaner and greener planet. Highlight why traffic rules matter and how they help save lives. Celebrate education as a right and show how learning fuels a brighter tomorrow. Imagine if public spaces could speak. Use your voice to protect and foster care for what belongs to all. Spread awareness on how to stay smart, safe and kind on the internet through your performance. Be a hero for our planet. Send a clear message to reduce waste, save energy or protect nature. Celebrate the power of free expression. Speak up about what matters to you. Stand a chance to win big and get recognized nationwide. Distributed across multiple categories and participation levels Get national recognition through coverage in Hindustan Times’ print and digital editions Every participant, semi-finalist, finalist, and winner receives an official certificate from Hindustan Times Mark your calendar with these key milestones for the competition. Introducing our esteemed jury panel who will evaluate your performances. Award-winning Filmmaker 20+ years of experience in directing and producing films across various genres. Theatre Director Renowned theatre personality with expertise in storytelling and performance arts. Vocal Coach Professional singer and vocal trainer with extensive experience in music education. Watch our standout performance that showcases the incredible talent and creativity of our participants. by Aisha Patel Everything you need to know about Hindustan Times The Next Voice competition The competition is open to students of classes 3 to 12 currently enrolled in any educational institution in India. You must have a valid student ID. Performances will be judged basis the jury evaluation and will be shortlisted for Semi Finale. The finalists will be decided considering jury’s feedback & voting. The winners will be decided by the jury. Yes, participants may submit multiple entries in each category, provided that every entry is unique and original. A fee of ₹ 199/- will be applicable for each submission. After submission, your video will go through a moderation process to ensure it meets our guidelines. Once approved, it will be featured in our gallery and evaluated by our judges. Shortlisted participants will be notified via email and invited for the live finale event. All participants will receive participation certificates. Empowering young voices through creative expression © 2025 Hindustan Times. All rights reserved. Get features like Indigo Flight Cancellation: IndiGo cancelled at least 150 flights on Wednesday, triggering chaotic scenes at major airports across India as the carrier’s struggles to adapt to stringent new crew rostering rules meant even minor operational disruptions snowballed into a full-blown crisis that stranded thousands of passengers. The airline apologised for the crippling disruption and warned travellers to brace for further cancellations through Friday, saying it had initiated “calibrated adjustments” to stabilise operations over the next 48 hours. “We acknowledge that IndiGo’s operations have been significantly disrupted across the network for the past two days, and we sincerely apologise to our customers for the inconvenience caused,” an airline spokesperson said, attributing the debacle to a confluence of factors including technology glitches, adverse weather, increased congestion and the implementation of updated Flight Duty Time Limitations (FDTL) that came into force in November. Also read: IndiGo apologises after over 150 flights cancelled, shares update on resolution The immediate trigger, however, was an emergency Airbus A320 software patch rushed through over the weekend of November 29-30 that disrupted crew scheduling just as the airline was operating with minimal slack due to the FDTL rules. Data from the Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA) shows the airline had already been under strain, having cancelled 1,232 flights in November—755 of them attributed to FDTL issues—with on-time performance dropping to 67.70% from 84.1% in October. Compounding the aviation chaos, IndiGo’s baggage systems at Delhi’s Terminal 1 and Terminal 3 encountered problems on Wednesday. “While the issue at T3 was minor, T1 faced severe issues starting at around 1.30pm and going up to around 6pm,” a government official said, adding that the baggage system had trouble providing information. The airline did not comment on this aspect but several passengers stated ground crews were unavailable. Also read: DGCA probes IndiGo flight disruption; asks airline to submit reasons, mitigation plans Turmoil erupted at airports in across the country with scenes of mounting passenger anger. At least 67 flights were cancelled at Delhi airport (37 departures and 30 arrivals), 42 at Bengaluru, 40 at Hyderabad (19 departures and 21 arrivals) and 33 at Mumbai (17 departures and 16 arrivals), according to airport officials. Social media was flooded with videos showing frustrated passengers remonstrating with airline staff. IndiGo flyers across the country had similar experiences, with flights simply scrapped as they turned up to check in. “We’ve been told that there’s a flight only after 5.30am on Thursday. We don’t stay in Delhi and they have not given us any accommodation,” said 76-year-old Gautam Patil in Delhi, who spent 40 hours travelling from Chicago with his 73-year-old wife, and were due to fly to Ahmedabad. Many said they missed onward connections. “I lost two connecting flights to Kochi because of this,” said Neha Mulay in Pune, who was set to travel on a Bengaluru-bound flight at 5.55am before it was delayed for four hours and then cancelled. Mohil Manish Shah, one of the passengers who travelled from Delhi to Mumbai in 6E-664 on Monday, said his flight was delayed for five hours and the airline staff kept the passengers uninformed. “When I reached Gate 34 at 5:45 pm, the gate agents informed me the flight was delayed by 15 minutes. This message kept repeating without any transparency. When passengers sought clarity, a customer representative stated one crew member had been called off at the last minute. We were then informed that the boarding would commence at 7.30pm. We were loaded onto buses to board the aircraft but had to wait in it for 30 minutes. The flight finally took off at 9.46pm.” Shah said he had to miss an important event due to the delay, for which he had paid a higher fare. The perfect storm According to people aware of the matter, the carrier has been beset by an acute pilot shortage since new FDTL norms were implemented in two phases on July 1 and November 1. The rules, designed to combat fatigue and boost rest periods, mandate increased weekly rest periods to 48 hours, extension of night hours, and limiting the number of night landings to two, down from six earlier. While the carrier had been managing the tighter crew constraints, people quoted above said the situation cascaded into crisis after the emergency Airbus software patch. The European Union Aviation Safety Agency issued an emergency airworthiness directive affecting approximately 6,000 A320-family aircraft globally after a JetBlue flight experienced an altitude drop on October 30, injuring passengers. In India, 200 of IndiGo’s 366 operational A320-family aircraft required the urgent software update. Though the airline completed the work and claimed “zero cancellations” at the time, a former airline official said the patch “did not lead to flight cancellations on Saturday but definitely delayed flights, causing expiry of the FDTL”. The official added that adverse weather around Chennai due to Cyclone Fengal on Sunday prevented the situation from improving. “The urgent safety mandate on A320 aircraft did not lead to flight cancellations on Saturday but definitely delayed flights, causing expiry of the FDTL. Moreover, airspace around Chennai had some impact on Sunday as well, not allowing the situation to get better,” the official said. The DGCA said on Wednesday it was investigating the situation and had summoned IndiGo to its headquarters “to present the facts leading to the current situation along with plans to mitigate the ongoing delays and cancellations”. Single-fleet strategy becomes Achilles heel The crisis has laid bare a critical vulnerability in IndiGo’s core business strategy. The airline has built its success on operating an almost exclusively Airbus A320-family fleet, a single-type approach that delivers cost savings through streamlined pilot training, simplified maintenance, reduced spare parts inventory and enormous bulk-purchase discounts and has been instrumental in helping IndiGo capture more than 60% of India’s domestic market. But when the Airbus emergency directive required more than half of IndiGo’s operational fleet to be taken in for urgent maintenance, the airline had no alternative aircraft types to deploy, unlike rivals such as Air India which operate diverse fleets including Boeing 737, 777s and 787s. The single-fleet strategy, long lauded as IndiGo’s competitive advantage, had turned into a single point of failure. IndiGo, which is known for its punctuality, recorded an on-time performance score of just 35% on Tuesday, according to official data—the lowest of all Indian airlines and a precipitous drop from the airline’s typical 80%-plus performance at major Indian airports. Wednesday’s figure would only be available on Thursday. The airline, which operates around 2,200-2,300 flights daily to over 90 domestic and 45 international destinations, said its teams were “working around the clock to ease customer discomfort and ensure operations stabilise as quickly as possible”. IndiGo said affected customers were being offered alternate travel arrangements to reach their destinations or refunds, as applicable. The airline requested customers to check the latest flight status at its website before heading to the airport. As of December 2, IndiGo had a total of 416 aircraft in its fleet, with 366 in operations and 50 on ground, up from 47 the previous month, according to aircraft fleet tracking website Planespotter.net. The Airline Pilots Association of India, which represents over 800 pilots, criticised what it called “a failure of proactive resource planning” by dominant airlines. “Despite sufficient time being accorded, most airlines started preparing rather late, failing to properly adjust crew rosters 15 days in advance as required,” the association said in a statement, suggesting the crisis pointed to “an initial managerial underestimation or delay in the strategic planning necessary to provision crew accordingly”.

Get features like Virat Kohli informed the Delhi and District Cricket Association (DDCA) that he will be available for the upcoming Vijay Hazare Trophy, marking his return to India’s domestic one-day tournament after a gap of 15 years. The decision, or rather, a change of mind, comes just a couple of days after his post-match comments in Ranchi about not needing additional preparation before international matches reportedly displeased the Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI). DDCA officials confirmed Kohli’s availability, saying it reflected the senior batter’s continued commitment to the game. "Virat has confirmed his availability for the Vijay Hazare Trophy. He will be playing matches at the Centre of Excellence". Delhi open their campaign against Andhra Pradesh in Alur on December 24. Kohli’s change of heart follows his remarks after scoring a match-winning 135 in the second ODI against South Africa on Sunday. “I’ve never been a big believer in a lot of preparation, if that makes sense. All my cricket has been mental. As long as I feel good mentally, I can play the game,” he had said, adding that the volume of cricket he has played over nearly two decades meant he did not feel the need to seek additional match practice. “I’ve played 300-odd ODI games and so much cricket over the last 15-16 years. If you can bat an hour and a half, two hours in the nets without taking a break, you’re meeting all the markers. I understand if there’s a dip in form, you look for games and try to get that form back,” Kohli said. He also stressed that for him, the focus remained on readiness rather than repetitions. “As long as you’re hitting the ball well and you’re playing good cricket, at this stage with the experience that I have, for me it’s about being physically fit, mentally ready and excited to play the games that I’m playing. Everything else should take care of itself.” According to a report in The Indian Express, Kohli's comments “had not gone down well” with the board, which had earlier instructed both Kohli and Rohit Sharma to participate in the domestic one-day competition to remain in contention for India’s ODI plans heading into the next phase of international cricket. Rohit had already informed the Mumbai Cricket Association of his availability, while Kohli had kept his decision pending until now. Kohli’s return to the domestic circuit comes at a time when speculation around the long-term ODI futures of both senior batters—Kohli, 37, and Rohit, 38—has been intensifying, especially with the next 50-over World Cup scheduled for 2027. Kohli, however, is showing no signs of slowing down. He registered back-to-back ODI centuries against South Africa to send a loud and clear message about his fitness and form.

cleaned_text: Subscribe Now! Get features like India is all set to welcome Russian President Vladimir Putin, his first visit to the country since Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Putin will arrive in Delhi on Thursday evening for the 23rd India-Russia annual summit. The talks during Putin's two-day visit will focus on deepening defence ties, as well as on trade and energy cooperation. Also read: 150 IndiGo flights cancelled as roster norms rock airline Some highlights of Putin's India visit agenda include meeting with President Droupadi Murmu, a private dinner hosted by Prime Minister Narendra Modi shortly after arriving in Delhi, discussion on trade and economic cooperation and other "promising projects" in industrial cooperation, innovative technologies, transport, peaceful space exploration, mining, healthcare and labour migration programmes, according to Putin's aide Yury Ushakov who noted that the bilateral political dialogue between India and Russia remains “regular and confidential”. Also read: Pete Hegseth's Signal chat use on Yemen strike put US troops at risk, finds Pentagon watchdog The President's visit also assumes significance as it comes months after the US's punitive actions against New Delhi, imposing 50% tariffs on Indian imports. cleaned_text: Subscribe Now! Get features like Hindustan Times proudly celebrates a century of unwavering commitment to truth and fearless journalism. Since 1924, we have been chronicling India’s journey—reporting pivotal moments and raising critical questions on issues of national & global importance. As India evolved, so did we. Hindustan Times became a symbol of leadership and the voice of the nation. From India’s first steps as a democracy to its giant leaps in science, sports, economy and beyond, we have been at the forefront, documenting the milestones that matter and shaping conversations that inspire progress. Our centennial celebrations are a tribute to this legacy of leadership. We showcased this with a stunning motion projection, transforming the iconic HT House in New Delhi into a luminous canvas that brought India’s rich history to life through an extraordinary visual spectacle. Celebrating the leaders of tomorrow, we hosted the Delhi leg of HT@100 Centennial Debate, where some of the brightest young minds came together to exchange ideas. This debate series fosters critical thinking and intellectual exchange, offering students a platform to showcase their oratory skills and engage in thought-provoking discussions on issues crucial to India’s future, reflecting our commitment to nurturing the leaders of tomorrow. Adding a flavorful twist to legacy, the HT@100 The Taste of Time was a celebration like no other. Michelin-starred chef Vikas Khanna and renowned columnist Vir Sanghvi came together to craft an unforgettable evening that captured the essence of India’s rich heritage with fine dining, live music and performing arts. For a remarkable celebration of leadership, there’s no platform greater than the Hindustan Times Leadership Summit. Marking our centenary, this year’s summit brought together visionaries including PM Narendra Modi, Dr. S. Jaishankar, John Kerry, K.M. Birla, Anil Agarwal, Akshay Kumar & many others to share ideas that inspire and shape the future. Marking this milestone in a way that engages every citizen, we have also launched HT@100 My Country My Lens, a photography contest inviting fellow citizens to capture the heart and soul of the nation – its rivers, borders, monuments and communities. As we embark on our next century, Hindustan Times remains steadfast in its mission to inform, inspire, and lead. With a legacy built on trust and a vision focused on the future, we invite you to be part of this journey. Follow the Hindustan Times website or simply subscribe to our Daily Capsule Newsletter to stay ahead of the curve with credible and unhyphenated journalism.

Get features like India-Russia collaboration not against anyone, aims to safeguard interests: Putin Russian President Vladimir Putin emphasized that the India-Russia partnership is not aimed against anyone, amid U.S. pressure on India regarding Russian oil and defense purchases. He highlighted the importance of collaboration in civil nuclear energy and defense while asserting that trade remains unaffected by political influences. Putin noted India's rising global influence and Modi's firm stance against external pressures. Straight from the stage: Musicians take on concert etiquette Concert etiquette is under scrutiny as fans disrupt performances, exemplified by incidents involving Akon and Tyga. Artistes and organizers emphasize the need for respectful behavior to ensure safety and enjoyment. Key guidelines include arriving on time, silencing phones, and respecting personal space. Proper conduct reflects India's global concert reputation, emphasizing music's intimate nature over social media sensationalism. IPBL: Chennai Super Warriors enter playoffs, Lucknow-Gurgaon in 3-3 draw Chennai Super Warriors secured a playoff spot in the Indian Pickleball League by defeating Bengaluru Blasters 4-2. Despite an early singles win by Bengaluru’s Phuc Huynh, Chennai rallied with strong performances in subsequent matches, culminating in a decisive Grand Rally victory. Meanwhile, Lucknow Leopards and Capital Warriors Gurgaon drew 3-3, while Mumbai Smashers lost to Hyderabad Royals 4-2. ‘Suryavanshi has got an amazing bat swing’ Mumbai's Vaibhav Suryavanshi, at just 14, became the youngest centurion in the T20 Syed Mushtaq Ali Trophy, scoring 108 runs against Maharashtra. Despite his impressive performance in the Asia Cup Rising Stars, where he averaged 59.75, Bihar lost the match. Experts highlight his unique batting style, drawing comparisons to legends like Brian Lara, emphasizing his potential to dominate in T20 cricket. Violent fight breaks out at Bihar wedding over rasgulla shortage, video goes viral A wedding in Bodh Gaya, Bihar, descended into chaos as a brawl erupted over a shortage of rasgullas, injuring several guests. The groom's family alleged a false dowry case was filed post-fight, while the bride's family canceled the wedding. The incident, captured on CCTV, has sparked viral reactions on social media, highlighting the absurdity of the situation. Special welcome from PM Modi, rare carpool and a dinner: Day 1 of Russian President Putin's India visit Russian President Vladimir Putin commenced a two-day visit to India, welcomed warmly by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. During the visit, which includes the 23rd Annual India-Russia Summit, key discussions will focus on defense, oil trade, and bilateral agreements. This marks Putin's first visit in over four years, emphasizing the historical India-Russia relations. Punjab has maximum cases of human trafficking: Jaishankar in Parliament External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar revealed in the Rajya Sabha that Punjab leads India in human trafficking cases, prompting the state government to form an SIT and a fact-finding committee. The NIA has also initiated investigations, resulting in numerous arrests. Other states like Haryana and Gujarat are also addressing the issue, indicating a nationwide response to trafficking. Pune land deal: Amadeia Enterprises justifies stamp duty waiver; order likely in five days Amadeia Enterprises LLP, led by Parth Pawar, has defended its stamp duty exemption in a disputed Mundhwa land deal, claiming eligibility despite a ₹42 crore notice from the Inspector General of Registration. The land, traditionally Mahar community property, requires government approval for transactions. Pawar has vowed to cancel the deal amid political scrutiny. The agreement was executed on May 20. Ludhiana: Elderly man dies post surgery, kin block road Tension erupted in Samrala as residents protested medical negligence following the death of 71-year-old Sohan Singh after gall bladder surgery. Alleging complications from a botched procedure, his family blocked the Khanna–Nawanshahr road for over an hour. Police assured action and a postmortem. The surgeon denied wrongdoing, attributing complications to the patient's condition. Pune air quality dips to ‘poor’; three stations cross 300 AQI mark Pune's air quality has sharply declined, entering the 'poor' category with AQI values exceeding 300 in key areas, including Shivajinagar and Lohegaon. Contributing factors include low temperatures, stagnant winds, and emissions from construction and traffic. Experts warn of further pollution spikes this winter unless effective measures like dust control and traffic management are implemented. Ludhiana: Schools lag behind in Centre-led activity after dept fails to issue timely notice District education officials in Ludhiana failed to notify government schools about the Indian Language Week, starting December 4, resulting in students missing the opening day's activities celebrating linguistic diversity. Despite a December 3 directive from SCERT Punjab, the communication was delayed, prompting disappointment among teachers. The deputy district education officer acknowledged the oversight, promising activities will continue from Friday. Ludhiana: Outsourced staff stage protest march, seek regular jobs Outsourced and contractual employees in Ludhiana protested for job regularization, demanding the government merge them into departments for permanent positions. The protest, led by Thekha Mulazam Sangharsh Morcha Punjab, highlighted the need for job security, minimum wages, and adherence to labor laws. Leaders criticized discriminatory policies and unjust conditions for regularization, emphasizing their long service contributions. Ludhiana: 2 dyeing units in Haibowal Dairy Complex asked to shut biz During an inspection led by Rajya Sabha member Balbir Singh Seechewal, two illegal dyeing units were discovered in Haibowal Dairy Complex, prompting the Punjab Pollution Control Board (PPCB) to order their closure. Seechewal reported significant improvements in the water quality of Buddha Nullah due to a campaign initiated last December to halt wastewater discharge from local dairies. Tiger Shroff: If my presence can motivate young athletes, that’s a privilege Tiger Shroff has joined Maharashtra CM Devendra Fadnavis's Project Mahadeva, aimed at developing football for under-13 athletes in the state. The initiative seeks to produce talent for India's 2034 FIFA World Cup squad. Shroff, passionate about football, emphasizes the importance of giving young athletes the exposure they need to realize their dreams in the sport. Olivia Nuzzi compares RFK Jr to Rocky in ‘strategy memo’ released by ex Ryan Lizza Olivia Nuzzi's affair with Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has ignited controversy, leading Ryan Lizza to end his engagement with her. Lizza shared a private note where Nuzzi compared Kennedy to Rocky Balboa and provided strategic advice for his presidential campaign. The memo included fashion tips and concluded with a heartfelt message, highlighting her involvement beyond journalism.
