text: Muslim man kills Hindu live-in partner? Delhi case falsely given communal angle
cleaned_text: This incident from Delhi has no communal angle. Virendra Singh killed his live‑in partner, Radha, after they had a heated argument over drinking. A Muslim man allegedly killed his Hindu live-in partner, stuffed her body in his car, and was on his way to dispose of it when the police caught him at a checkpoint. This allegation has been widely shared online alongside a Hindi TV9 Bharatvarsh headline that reads: “In Delhi, man murders live-in partner, stores her body in a car and goes to sleep.” The headline was shared with captions like, “My Abdul is different... Abdul has committed another crime. He killed his loving partner, a Hindu girl, in Delhi and was taking her body into his car to dispose of it... On the way, his car was caught during police checking, and it was found that he had killed the Hindu woman living with him." The name Abdul is often used as a euphemism for Muslims on social media. India Today Fact Check found that this incident took place on November 26 in Delhi. The person accused of murdering his live-in partner, however, is a Hindu man called Virendra Singh.OUR PROBE We searched TV9 Bharatvarsh’s social media accounts and found the same graphic in a November 27 Facebook post, which also contained a link to a news report. Curiously, the report’s details did not match the viral claim. According to TV9 Bharatvarsh, 35-year-old Virendra Singh strangled his live-in girlfriend to death following a dispute over drinking alcohol. He left her body in his car and went to sleep drunk. In the morning, a neighbour's complaint led to the police recovering the body and arresting Singh. No communal angle was mentioned in the report. Subsequently, we found more news reports about the incident. According to The Times of India, the victim was a 44-year-old woman named Radha. She was murdered by her live-in partner, Virendra Singh, who was already married and had kids. Reportedly, Singh was heavily intoxicated when he killed Radha. He carried her body to his car with the help of two other associates. Per the report, he intended to dispose of the body later but fell asleep before he could do so. A police officer told the Indian Express, “The house they were living in is in Virender’s name. He had convinced the woman to sell her own house in Palam and bought the three-storey house, which they were currently living in, with the money made from the sale. Cash worth Rs 21 lakh was found in the house.” According to a police statement, on the morning of November 26, the Chhawla police station received a PCR call. When the police reached the spot at Najafgarh’s Deenpur Extension, they found a Swift car locked and parked with a woman’s dead body on the rear seat. Upon interrogation, Virendra Singh admitted his guilt and said that when the victim asked him not to drink, they got into a quarrel. During this, he strangulated her and put her body in his car. Speaking to India Today Fact Check, DCP Dwarka, Ankit Kumar Singh, confirmed there was no communal angle to the case, and both the victim and the killer were Hindu. Thus, it’s clear that the viral claim is false. (Written by Aryama Bhattacharjee)- EndsPublished By: Pathikrit SanyalPublished On: Dec 4, 2025
label: fake

text: 'Not doing anything wrong': Meet the man who's making your private data public
cleaned_text: On December 1, we published a report about a website called ProxyEarth.org that allows you to fetch the personal data (address, ID proof, alternate numbers, etc.) of Indians using only phone numbers. While the website had not been blocked in India at the time of writing this, in the aftermath of our report, it began running at a reduced capacity, often with glitches. Nevertheless, we decided to dig deeper. India Today Fact Check’s investigation led us to a man who identifies himself as Rakesh, one of the key persons behind ProxyEarth.org. While this might not be his real name, we will henceforth refer to him as such for convenience. Under the pretext of purchasing leaked data in bulk for marketing, we spoke to Rakesh at length. And among other things, Rakesh said he had done no wrong in creating this website.Who is ‘Rakesh’? Rakesh has a fairly wide but anonymous presence online. But we managed to connect his many accounts thanks to a common element: his profile photo, which is an anime-style portrait of a young man wearing a plaid shirt and featuring the Indian flag and the logos of CapCut and Adobe After Effects. We found Instagram, X, and YouTube accounts featuring the same photo. All of these accounts share more or less the same type of content: hacks for pirating premium video editing apps, sending bulk messages, temporary OTPs, live webcams, etc.We were still looking for a face when we found the Threads account connected to his Instagram. It had a different profile photo — not exactly a real face, but something close. It appears to be a heavily edited version of a real person’s face, with the same After Effects logo in the back. We aren’t sure if this is actually Rakesh.How we found himUpon examining the source code (backend) of the website, we found mention of a Telegram channel called “@uploadfileofficial”. On that channel, we found the link to another Telegram channel called “@rakeshxofficial”.On “@rakeshxofficial”, he identified himself as an editor and a programmer. Both channels had the same profile photos mentioned earlier.‘I did nothing wrong’While investigating the web of multiple social media accounts, websites, and Telegram channels, we found a phone number. We then called this number on the pretext of buying a package of leaked data.Rakesh believed us and asked for details about the kind of data we wanted. During this conversation, he said that he worked with a team of 10–12 people, who had together created the ProxyEarth.org website. He said that this was only one of their many projects.advertisementRakesh also claimed that he was from Bihar, from a town bordering Eastern Uttar Pradesh. This matched with his number’s TrueCaller information.Rakesh said that he was not doing anything wrong. He told us that he was not responsible for any of the data breaches — he was only using existing data leaks to power the website. He said that he had only merged multiple such databases for this website.We found that whenever you enter a mobile number on the website, it initiates an API call to connect with leaked databases at the backend. As we mentioned in our previous story, there have been reports of several major leaks related to Indians in the last couple of years.Why did he do this?For Rakesh, the opportunity to access people’s personal data was just a bait. He wanted people to explore his other ventures, which are his actual source of income.As mentioned above, Rakesh advertises hacks for pirating premium video editing apps, live webcams, and other services on his social media. He told India Today Fact Check, “I am using this website as a platform to attract traffic and to advertise my other products.”advertisementWhen we pointed out that the Department of Telecom may soon block his website, Rakesh said calmly that creating a replica with a different domain name would not be difficult at all.- EndsPublished By: Pathikrit SanyalPublished On: Dec 2, 2025 We found Instagram, X, and YouTube accounts featuring the same photo. All of these accounts share more or less the same type of content: hacks for pirating premium video editing apps, sending bulk messages, temporary OTPs, live webcams, etc. We were still looking for a face when we found the Threads account connected to his Instagram. It had a different profile photo — not exactly a real face, but something close. It appears to be a heavily edited version of a real person’s face, with the same After Effects logo in the back. We aren’t sure if this is actually Rakesh. How we found him Upon examining the source code (backend) of the website, we found mention of a Telegram channel called “@uploadfileofficial”. On that channel, we found the link to another Telegram channel called “@rakeshxofficial”. On “@rakeshxofficial”, he identified himself as an editor and a programmer. Both channels had the same profile photos mentioned earlier. ‘I did nothing wrong’ While investigating the web of multiple social media accounts, websites, and Telegram channels, we found a phone number. We then called this number on the pretext of buying a package of leaked data. Rakesh believed us and asked for details about the kind of data we wanted. During this conversation, he said that he worked with a team of 10–12 people, who had together created the ProxyEarth.org website. He said that this was only one of their many projects. Rakesh also claimed that he was from Bihar, from a town bordering Eastern Uttar Pradesh. This matched with his number’s TrueCaller information. Rakesh said that he was not doing anything wrong. He told us that he was not responsible for any of the data breaches — he was only using existing data leaks to power the website. He said that he had only merged multiple such databases for this website. We found that whenever you enter a mobile number on the website, it initiates an API call to connect with leaked databases at the backend. As we mentioned in our previous story, there have been reports of several major leaks related to Indians in the last couple of years.Why did he do this? For Rakesh, the opportunity to access people’s personal data was just a bait. He wanted people to explore his other ventures, which are his actual source of income. As mentioned above, Rakesh advertises hacks for pirating premium video editing apps, live webcams, and other services on his social media. He told India Today Fact Check, “I am using this website as a platform to attract traffic and to advertise my other products.” When we pointed out that the Department of Telecom may soon block his website, Rakesh said calmly that creating a replica with a different domain name would not be difficult at all.- EndsPublished By: Pathikrit SanyalPublished On: Dec 2, 2025
label: fake

text: Privacy nightmare: Your personal data is now out in the open — just a click away
cleaned_text: A massive Indian data leak appears to have become publicly available. A website called ProxyEarth.org now lets you search for anyone’s personal information by just entering their phone number! The website has a sleek, easy-to-use user interface. All you have to do is input an Indian mobile number. The website says it works only for numbers starting with 6, 7, 8, or 9. When you enter the mobile number, the site appears to run commands and then triangulate the location on a map. It even seems to show the network strength of the number at that location. The website also shows your name, address, father’s name, an alternate mobile number, the name of your cellular service, email address, and either an Aadhaar, voter ID, PAN, or a driving licence number. As many people are flagging it on social media tagging the government, it is possible that the site might be blocked.What you should worry about The other data, when available, is largely accurate, if not up to date. The data available on the website appears to be information provided at the time of buying a SIM card: name, father’s name, home address, alternate number, and ID proof. There may be a silver lining for some people here. The data appears outdated in many cases. In several instances, we found old addresses and even old network carriers (which may have been ported to new carriers since). This indicates that the data is most likely old and from when one parched the SIM card.What not to worry about The website does not track live locations. Nor does it show the number bars your device has. These features are there to add more credibility to it. The live location was wrong in every instance we checked, where we knew the person’s current location. The network strength gives the impression of live tracking. But the “good” or “bad” rating alongside it likely indicates how much data is part of the leak. This means a “good” rating is bad news. And vice versa. One can also see a “Live” logo in the upper right corner of the screen. This is also an embellishment to add to the website’s credibility for “live tracking” and is misleading.What is ProxyEarth.org? According to WhoIs, a tool that tells you details about any site’s registration, the website was created on October 17 this year.Recent data breaches As of now, it appears that this might not be a new data breach. Rather, someone has likely compiled data from older breaches — already available for sale on the dark web — in an easy-to-use interface. In January 2024, personal data, including the names of mobile users, their phone numbers, residential addresses, Aadhaar details, and names of family members of nearly 75 crore Indians, were reported to be put up for sale online. And in 2023, an American cybersecurity company said that personally identifiable information of 81.5 crore Indian citizens, including Aadhaar numbers and passport details, was being sold on the dark web for $80,000. To check if your personal data has been part of an existing leak, search for your email address on haveibeenpwned.com. It is advisable not to run ProxyEarth.org on your mobile device, as we do not know who is behind this website and what their motives are.- EndsPublished By: Pathikrit SanyalPublished On: Dec 1, 2025
label: fake

text: Fact Check: Did goons attack fish markets in Bengal? No, this video is from Delhi
cleaned_text: The video is from the Gokulpuri area in New Delhi where a Hindu group threatened vendors for selling meat and fish close to a temple. A video is being widely shared online with claims that it shows a tense scene of a group of men threatening a local fish seller and other meat shop owners in West Bengal. In the video, one man starts vandalising a fish vendor's shop, threatening: “No meat should be visible around.” The video was shared with captions like: “Shocking: Reportedly, a group of goons entered a fish market in Bengal and vandalised several local fish shops. So now they want to stop Bengalis from eating fish too?” India Today Fact Check found that the incident happened in the Gokulpuri area of Delhi on November 27.OUR PROBE A reverse image search of the video’s keyframes led to a longer video on Instagram, which identified the location and date. The video was captioned: “Hindu nationalist supporters forcibly evicted meat sellers and shut down their shops, citing the presence of a nearby temple.” The location was listed as Delhi’s Gokulpuri, and the date was November 27. A closer look at the footage revealed "Gokulpuri" clearly visible on several walls, confirming the incident's location. In the comments of this video, we also observed that many had tagged the account of one Rahul Pachauri, the man allegedly behind these attacks. We checked his Instagram account (@hindu_52_07), and found the viral video shared on November 28 with the caption: “There was news coming from Gokulpuri area that meat trading was taking place within 30 metres of the temple by Hindu and Muslim traders despite previously being warned by the police. Hindu youths banded together and warned the meat traders that if they want to do this in future, do it at a distance from the temple. If someone is found doing business around the temple, legal action will be taken against them.” We found another video shared by the account the same day, captioned, “Meat trade was going on in Gokulpuri. Today, a warning has been given openly that meat trade will be removed from the temple soon. Otherwise, police action will be taken.” In the video, Pachauri asserted that they were enforcing a specific rule: that meat vendors must maintain a distance of at least 500 metres from any religious place. Failure to do so would result in police action. The man in the viral video threatening the fish vendor can be seen in this video, standing behind Pachauri. We found his Instagram account, which stated that his name is Aakash Pandat. We reached out to Rahul Pachauri to verify the details of the incident. He confirmed to India Today Fact Check that it took place on November 27, between 6 and 7 pm. He claimed he was falsely accused of specifically targeting Muslim-owned shops. According to him, he had no animosity towards Muslims. His concern, he said, was that meat shops should not operate near a temple. He added that he and his companions, who were detained by the police, have since been released. Notably, we also did not find any credible news reports of meat traders being harassed in West Bengal recently. Thus, it is clear that the viral video has been shared with misleading claims. (Written by Aryama Bhattacharjee)- EndsPublished By: Pathikrit SanyalPublished On: Dec 1, 2025
label: fake

text: Fact Check: UP wedding ruckus viral as RSS attack on Catholic school in Telangana
cleaned_text: This video actually shows a crowd looting snacks and other food items at a mass wedding in Hamirpur, UP. A video of a large crowd creating a ruckus is making the rounds on social media. In it, people can be seen rushing hither and thither, hurling cartons. Those sharing the video claimed that it was from Telangana, where Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh workers attacked a Catholic school. Sharing the video on X, one person wrote, “After attacking Muslims, RSS extremists have now turned their violence towards Christians. At St. Mother Teresa Catholic School in Mancherial, Telangana, they attacked the principal, Fr. Raimon Joseph, and forcibly marked his forehead with a tilak. This is not Gandhi’s India.” India Today Fact Check found that the video actually shows a crowd looting snacks and other food items at a wedding in Uttar Pradesh’s Hamirpur.OUR PROBE Reverse searching keyframes from the viral video led us to the same clip shared by Jist News on Instagram on November 27. Its caption noted that at a mass wedding in Uttar Pradesh’s Hamirpur, chaos ensued when people rushed toward the snack counters after the ceremonies, leading to a stampede-like situation. Several people reportedly fell and were injured. View this post on Instagram A post shared by Jist (@jist.news) We found several news reports about the incident. According to an Indian Express report, it was a government-sponsored mass wedding held on November 25 at the playground of Swami Brahmanand Vidyalaya in Rath town. Guests rushed to grab snacks and looted boxes of chips and other food items. Moreover, we found no credible news reports of any recent attack on a Catholic school in Telangana. However, in April 2024, a school in Telangana was attacked over a saffron clothing dispute. As per a report by the Indian Express, a missionary-run school in the Mancherial district was attacked by a group of villagers after students dressed in saffron religious clothing were reportedly informed that their parents needed prior approval for them to attend school without the standard uniform. As per reports, some men surrounded Principal Joseph, beat him up, and forcibly applied a tilak on his forehead. Thus, it is evident that the video does not show an RSS attack on a Catholic school in Telangana.- EndsPublished By: Pathikrit SanyalPublished On: Nov 28, 2025
label: fake

text: Fact Check: Did Lawrence Bishnoi just get bail? No, this is an old video
cleaned_text: The video is from 2020 and shows Bishnoi being presented before the court in Fazilka. He is still lodged at Sabarmati Central Jail in Ahmedabad. A video going viral on social media allegedly shows gangster Lawrence Bishnoi being released on bail. The video shows the gangster being escorted by police officers. In the video, the location was identified as Fazilka, a district in Punjab where Bishnoi was born. A reporter in the video asks Bishnoi how he felt, to which he responds in Hindi, “It feels great. Hopefully, all other cases turn out like this one.” India Today Fact Check found that the video is from 2020. Bishnoi hasn’t been granted bail.OUR PROBE We did not find any credible news reports about Lawrence Bishnoi being granted bail. He is currently imprisoned in Sabarmati Central Jail in Ahmedabad, Gujarat. According to an Indian Express report, the Ministry of Home Affairs renewed its order in August this year to restrict his movement for another year. A reverse image search led us to a longer version of the video, uploaded to YouTube by RB Live Media on February 24, 2020. According to the information provided by RB Live Media, the video is from the same day when Bishnoi was produced in the Fazilka court in Punjab. This was in connection with an attempted murder case under Section 307 of the Indian Penal Code. He was acquitted on that charge. Recently, the Bishnoi gang returned to the headlines when, on November 19, Anmol Bishnoi, Lawrence’s younger brother, was brought back from the United States of America to India and handed over to the National Investigation Agency. Anmol is wanted in connection with the killing of Nationalist Congress Party leader Baba Siddique, a shooting at actor Salman Khan’s residence, and the murder of Punjabi singer Sidhu Moosewala, among other charges. He has been absconding since 2022. Therefore, we can conclude that the video being shared does not show Lawrence Bishnoi being granted bail. (written by Aryama Bhattacharjee)- EndsPublished By: Pathikrit SanyalPublished On: Nov 26, 2025
label: fake

text: Fact Check: This clip DOES NOT show student dying after 100 sit-ups as punishment
cleaned_text: This video does not show the Maharashtra student who died after a 100 sit-up punishment. It shows an eight-year-old who suffered a cardiac arrest and died on January 10 in Ahmedabad. No news reports about this incident mention corporal punishment as a cause. In Maharashtra’s Vasai, a 13-year-old schoolgirl reportedly died after being subjected to corporal punishment for being late. The class VI student was allegedly made to do 100 sit-ups as punishment for arriving late on November 8. The student, Anshika Gaud — though news reports have also used the name Kajal Gaud — was reportedly suffering from a pre-existing medical condition, experienced difficulty in breathing later that day, and was hospitalised. She died on November 14. A video now going viral shows a schoolgirl collapsing onto a bench in a school corridor. Those sharing the clip claimed that this eight-year-old collapsed and died after being punished with 100 sit-ups for arriving late to school. A Facebook user shared the video and wrote, “8 Years Old Died Due to Cardiac Arrest After 100 Sit-ups Punishment in School.” India Today Fact Check India Today Fact Check found that while this video does show an eight-year-old dying because of cardiac arrest, it has nothing to do with corporal punishment. Here’s what we found:OUR PROBE A reverse image search of keyframes from the viral clip led us to the same video shared by an X account on January 10. The Gujarati caption stated that an eight-year-old student named Gargi Ranpara died after experiencing chest pain at Zebar School in Ahmedabad’s Thaltej. This makes it evident that the video is not recent and has nothing to do with the death of the 13-year-old schoolgirl from Vasai. 8 !| 8 . 8 . .pic.twitter.com/KLRudt3qhx— Sagar Patoliya (@kathiyawadiii) January 10, 2025 We found several news reports about this incident, which said that the girl, Gargi Ranpara, died after collapsing at Zebar School for Children in Thaltej, Ahmedabad, on January 10. Gargi, a third-grader, became unwell shortly after arriving and slumped on a bench in the school corridor. Teachers quickly rushed her to Asarwa Civil Hospital. Sharmistha Sinha, the principal of the school, stated, "The girl had no prior health issues. Doctors informed us that Gargi had suffered a cardiac arrest. They attempted to revive her and placed her on a ventilator support, but unfortunately, she did not survive." Atul Tiwari, the Ahmedabad correspondent for India Today, who covered the story, confirmed the information, stating, "On the morning of January 10, Gargi Ranpara climbed the stairs to school and suffered a cardiac arrest. This incident is unrelated to the 100 sit-ups or any other punishment administered by the school teachers." According to a January 11 Times of India report, hospital authorities informed the police after Gargi's death. The police thereafter launched an investigation and sent her body for postmortem examination to determine the exact cause of her death. Bodakdev police inspector Apurva Patel said a case of accidental death had been lodged. We did not find any news reports about what a medical examiner's post-mortem report found. It is, however, evident that the viral video has nothing to do with the student who died after doing 100 sit-ups as punishment.- EndsPublished By: Pathikrit SanyalPublished On: Nov 26, 2025
label: fake

text: Fact Check: Loot on the streets of UP? This video is actually AI-generated
cleaned_text: Neither is this video from Uttar Pradesh, nor does it show a real incident. It’s AI-generated. A video that’s going viral on social media allegedly shows people in Uttar Pradesh looting money from the streets after a truck full of cash overturned on a highway. In the video, we can see a broken-down, overturned vehicle in a street littered with cash, and people rushing to grab it. The video was shared with captions like: “Cash started flying on the road after a truck full of cash overturned on the highway of Uttar Pradesh. Seeing this, about 500 people gathered on the spot and looted the notes.” India Today Fact Check found out that neither is the video from UP, nor did such an incident occur recently. This video is AI-generated.OUR PROBE If such an incident had actually happened, it would have been in the news. However, we found no credible news reports about it from either Uttar Pradesh or the rest of India. When we had a closer look at the video, we found some telltale clues that indicate it’s an AI-generated video. One, the video has a smooth, glossy texture that’s typical of synthetic media. Two, the limbs and faces of people in the crowd appeared distorted in many instances. Third, an autorickshaw visible in the video was misshapen and also did not have a door on its side at all. These clues and many others hinted at the video being AI-generated. On reverse-searching keyframes from the video, we found it was shared by an Instagram account named Arshad Arsh Edits. Its caption clearly states that this video is AI-generated, created for entertainment purposes. The account features numerous other AI-generated videos, and its bio also mentions “Animations Memes & AI Video Editor”. We also examined the video using an AI-detection tool. Hive Moderation indicated a 99 per cent likelihood that this video was created using AI. Therefore, it’s clear that the video does not show a real incident at all.- EndsPublished By: Pathikrit SanyalPublished On: Nov 25, 2025
label: fake

text: Fact Check: Viral video DOES NOT show illegals running away from WB amid SIR drive
cleaned_text: The viral video actually shows a Shyama Puja immersion procession from October 30 in West Bengal’s Foonkotla. As West Bengal undergoes the Special Intensive Revision of electoral rolls, social media has been flooded with alarming claims. A video going viral right now purports to show undocumented Bangladeshi immigrants fleeing India because of the SIR drive in West Bengal. Several people, who shared this video, shared the clip with captions like, “BREAKING | Movement at Indo–Bangladesh Border,” and “A rush of Bangladeshis is heading back after SIR orders were issued in West Bengal.” India Today Fact Check found that the viral video shows the Shyama Puja immersion in West Bengal’s Foonkotla. It is not related to the SIR drive at all. Upon reverse searching, we found the profile of a woman who appeared in the same crowd. On her Facebook page, she had posted a live video on October 30, captioned: “Foonkotla Shyama Maa farewell”, referring to the immersion procession of Shyama Puja/Kaali Puja in Foonkotla, a West Bengal village near the Indo-Bangladesh border. While comparing her Facebook Live video with the viral clip, we found the same people were visible in both videos. The background matched, including the barbed-wire fencing. The setting confirmed that the video was indeed from the West Bengal-Bangladesh border belt. Another 7-minute-52-second-long video ( https://www.facebook.com/reel/3867361026895047 ) posted by the same user from the same date and location shows people carrying a Kali idol for immersion, further establishing that this was a festival procession and not linked to the SIR drive. Most importantly, the video is from October 30, before the SIR process began in West Bengal on November 4. Hence, it cannot be connected to the ongoing SIR.SIR IN BENGALEven though the video is unrelated, the ongoing situation in West Bengal explains why many were quick to connect the two. India Today’s ground report found that many illegal immigrants, who had entered India illegally years ago and managed to obtain Aadhaar and voter ID cards, are now seeking to return to Bangladesh amid the SIR operation.advertisementReportedly, since July, 200–300 people have been reaching the border daily to return to Bangladesh. Officials link this steady outflow to the ongoing voter list revision.So, while the viral video does not show the exodus of illegal immigrants in West Bengal, this is something that has been happening in the state for some time, which has now intensified since the SIR exercise began.- Ends(Written by Rashmi Gupta, with inputs from Riddhish Dutta)Published By: sharangee Published On: Nov 22, 2025Tune InMust Watch The background matched, including the barbed-wire fencing. The setting confirmed that the video was indeed from the West Bengal-Bangladesh border belt. Another 7-minute-52-second-long video ( https://www.facebook.com/reel/3867361026895047 ) posted by the same user from the same date and location shows people carrying a Kali idol for immersion, further establishing that this was a festival procession and not linked to the SIR drive. Most importantly, the video is from October 30, before the SIR process began in West Bengal on November 4. Hence, it cannot be connected to the ongoing SIR.SIR IN BENGAL Even though the video is unrelated, the ongoing situation in West Bengal explains why many were quick to connect the two. India Today’s ground report found that many illegal immigrants, who had entered India illegally years ago and managed to obtain Aadhaar and voter ID cards, are now seeking to return to Bangladesh amid the SIR operation. Reportedly, since July, 200–300 people have been reaching the border daily to return to Bangladesh. Officials link this steady outflow to the ongoing voter list revision. So, while the viral video does not show the exodus of illegal immigrants in West Bengal, this is something that has been happening in the state for some time, which has now intensified since the SIR exercise began.- Ends(Written by Rashmi Gupta, with inputs from Riddhish Dutta)Published By: sharangee Published On: Nov 22, 2025Tune InMust Watch
label: fake

text: Illegal immigrants rush to Sealdah station post SIR? Here are the facts
cleaned_text: The video is indeed from Sealdah Station, but it has nothing to do with SIR. It, in fact, predates the announcement of SIR in West Bengal. Since the Special Intensive Revision of electoral rolls commenced in West Bengal, illegal immigrants have reportedly begun leaving the state for Bangladesh. A video now going viral on social media purports to show a massive crowd of Rohingya passengers rushing at the Sealdah railway station in West Bengal. One X user shared the video and wrote: "SIR comes to Bengal. Rohingyas run from Bengal. Sealdah railway station". India Today Fact Check found that the video is indeed from Sealdah station, but it has nothing to do with SIR. Also, it predates the announcement of SIR in West Bengal. With the help of Google Lens, we found the same video in a Facebook post from October 15. It is to be noted that the Election Commission of India announced the second phase of the SIR in 12 states and Union Territories, including West Bengal, on October 27. So, the viral video cannot be linked to the ongoing SIR drive in the state. The Facebook user who uploaded the video on October 15, Tofick Khan, wrote in the caption that a ruckus erupted at Sealdah Station as two children fell during a heavy rush of passengers from two trains. Apart from this, we found that he had also shared a clarification video about the viral claim on November 5. As per Khan, he had come to Sealdah Station from Lalgola on October 15. When he arrived, he found that another train had been announced on the same line. Apart from this, we found that he had also shared a clarification video about the viral claim on November 5. As per Khan, he had come to Sealdah Station from Lalgola on October 15. When he arrived, he found that another train had been announced on the same line. The announcement caused panic among the passengers, who started rushing out quickly from the train. Because of this, some children fell on the platform. Khan recorded the whole incident and shared the video on social media. We compared the Lalgola–Sealdah passenger train’s scheduled arrival time at Sealdah station with the time displayed on the platform clock in the viral video. The clock shows 16.19, or 4.19 pm, at the moment when the video was being recorded. The Lalgola–Sealdah passenger train is scheduled to reach Sealdah at around 4 pm. However, it gets delayed sometimes. Also, a train leaves Sealdah for Lalgola at 4.10 pm. It is possible that the small time margin between the trains and routine delays could create panic among the passengers. This provides validity to Khan's version of events. Notably, since the announcement of the SIR drive in West Bengal, there has reportedly been a surge of undocumented immigrants leaving the state for Bangladesh. This video, however, does not show that. - EndsPublished By: Sahil SinhaPublished On: Nov 22, 2025Tune InMust Watch
label: fake

text: Fact Check: Bangladesh road rage video FALSELY shared as attack on Yunus press sec
cleaned_text: The video does not show Muhammaed Yunus's deputy press secretary. It’s a road rage incident, likely from Dhaka. On November 17, former Bangladesh Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina was sentenced to death in absentia by the International Crimes Tribunal. Hasina, who is currently exiled in India, was found guilty of crimes against humanity for allowing lethal force that prosecutors claim resulted in over 1,400 protester deaths. She has vehemently denied the accusations, labelling the trial as "biased and politically motivated." Amid all this, a video allegedly showing the deputy press secretary to Bangladesh’s Chief Advisor Muhammad Yunus getting attacked in the middle of the road has gone viral. Responding to such posts, many commented on how law and order were rapidly collapsing in Dhaka following the death sentence. India Today Fact Check found, however, that the video has been online since as early as September 2025, and the person in the video is not Yunus’s deputy press secretary.OUR PROBE A reverse image search led us to a longer version of the footage uploaded by the news organisation News Now Bangla on October 15. We also found another clip of the incident shared on September 30. All of this proves that this video predates Sheikh Hasina’s death sentence. In the video, we noticed a Bangladeshi number plate on one of the cars, indicating that the video was indeed from the country. When we compared the face of the man in the car being attacked with bothdeputy press secretaries to Yunus in Bangladesh, Apurba Jahangir and Azad Majumdar. The comparison given below makes it clear that neither secretary is in the viral video. Further, had Jahangir been publicly attacked, it would have made the national news in Bangladesh. We found no credible news reports about any such incident. India Today Fact Check reached out to the assistant press secretary to Muhammad Yunus, Nayem Ali, who confirmed no such incident has occurred and that the man in the video was not affiliated to Yunus’s press office. A Dhaka-based news organisation named, The Dissent, also debunked this claim. It reported that the deputy press secretary was not assaulted and noted that this was just a road-rage incident from the Gulshan area of Dhaka. Thus, it is evident that the viral claim is patently false.- EndsBy Aryama BhattacharjeePublished By: Vivek Published On: Nov 20, 2025
label: fake

text: Fact Check: This video of poll panel chief Gyanesh Kumar, Amit Shah is AI-generated
cleaned_text: This video is not real. It has been created with the help of Artificial Intelligence. After the Bihar Assembly elections, several opposition parties, including the Congress, have raised questions over the impartiality of the Election Commission. A video now going viral purports to show Chief Election Commissioner Gyanesh Kumar bowing at the feet of Home Minister Amit Shah. One Facebook user wrote in Hindi alongside the viral video: “The Election Commission at the feet! Those who want to know why such results came in the Bihar elections can watch this video and understand the truth. In this video, the supreme sycophant, Chief Election Commissioner Gyanesh Kumar, is seen kissing the feet of his master. Earlier, this gentleman was also his personal secretary. Those who are supposed to protect democracy while holding constitutional posts in India are brutally murdering democracy.” India Today Fact Check found that this video was created with the help of AI tools — it’s not real. We observed several anomalies in the video. For example, when Gyanesh Kumar drapes the shawl over Amit Shah, the other end of the shawl automatically reaches down to Amit Shah’s hand on its own. Also, both of them hold each other’s hands for an unnaturally long time. When we reverse-searched the keyframes of the video, we found an identical photo on the website of Content Garden. In it, Gyanesh Kumar can be seen draping a shawl over Amit Shah’s shoulders. According to the information given there, this photo was from 2023 when Gyanesh Kumar was serving as Secretary in the Ministry of Cooperation. On November 8, 2023, a national symposium was held in New Delhi to promote organic products. In the programme organised by National Cooperative Organics Limited, Gyanesh Kumar honoured Home Minister Amit Shah. According to a PIB press release, Amit Shah was the chief guest at this event. We found the video of this programme on the YouTube channel of Krishi Jagran Business. At the beginning of the video, Gyanesh Kumar can be seen honouring Home Minister Shah by draping a shawl and presenting a bouquet. But he does not bow in front of the Home Minister in the manner shown in the viral video. Clearly, this portion of the video was created using AI. We also tested the video with an AI detection tool. According to WasItAI, this video was generated using AI. Thus, it’s clear that the viral video is not real!- EndsPublished By: Pathikrit SanyalPublished On: Nov 18, 2025
label: fake

text: Fact Check: Protest in Bihar against 'vote chori'? No, this video is from Gujarat
cleaned_text: This video from November 15 from Gujarat’s Netrang town shows AAP MLA Chaitar Vasava leading a rally on the occasion of Birsa Munda’s birth anniversary. Following the landslide victory of the National Democratic Alliance in the Bihar Assembly elections, many shared a video of a large crowd marching on a road. Allegedly, the video showed people of Bihar protesting against vote theft. The caption of the video read, “Entire Bihar came on the road to stop vote chori.” India Today Fact Check found that the video is not from Bihar, but from Gujarat. It is unrelated to the just-concluded Bihar Assembly polls. Reverse-searching keyframes from the viral video led us to a similar video on Instagram, dated November 15. This video’s Gujarati-language caption translates to, “Chaitar Vasava is a different kind of fun.” Alongside the captions, hashtags like “Chaitar Vasava” and “Netrang” were also used. Chaitar Vasava is an Aam Aadmi Party MLA from Gujarat’s Dediapada constituency, and Netrang is a small town in Gujarat’s Bharuch district, adjoining the Dediapada seat. Subsequent searches led us to a couple of reports published in the Dainik Bhaskar English and the Navbharat Times, dated November 16. Per these reports, Chaitar Vasava led a massive rally in Netrang on November 15 on the occasion of Birsa Munda’s 150th birth anniversary. These reports noted that the rallies showcased Adivasi unity. Vasava also shared a glimpse of this rally on his X account. 150 - , , - # #Birsa_munda pic.twitter.com/7nLtl7xIG9— Chaitar Vasava AAP (@Chaitar_Vasava) November 15, 2025 We also found out the exact location where the viral video was recorded. We found a three-story building and an adjoining clothing store visible in the video on Google Maps Street View, on the Ankleshwar-Burhanpur highway. Notably, Prime Minister Narendra Modi also held a rally in Dediapada on November 15 and paid tribute to Birsa Munda on his birth anniversary. Therefore, it is beyond any doubt that an unrelated video from Gujarat was falsely shared as a protest against alleged vote theft in Bihar.- EndsPublished By: Pathikrit SanyalPublished On: Nov 18, 2025Must Watch
label: fake

text: Fact Check: Is Pak Army mobilising troops after Delhi terror attack? Viral video is OLD
cleaned_text: While it’s likely from Pakistan, this video has been online since as early as April, and is therefore not related to the terror attack in Delhi. The Centre assured Indians on November 12 that the perpetrators and sponsors of the terror attack near the Red Fort would be brought to justice swiftly. According to news reports, Pakistan-based outfits Jaish-e-Mohammad and Ansar Ghazwat-ul-Hind may be linked to the terror module that was nabbed in Faridabad the morning of the attack. Now, a five-second-long video of a train carrying military tanks is being widely shared online. Allegedly, it shows the Pakistan army mobilising its troops from Balochistan to the Indian border, fearing retaliation from India. Sharing the video on X, one user wrote, “Fearing Indian retaliation after the Delhi Blast, Pakistan Army is moving troops, Arms and ammunition from Balochistan to the Indian border. With PoK, Balochistan will also get freedom.” India Today Fact Check, however, found that the video clip has been online since as early as April, and is therefore not related to the terror attack in Delhi.OUR PROBE Reverse-searching a screenshot from the video led us to the same clip shared on TikTok. We checked the date of upload, which said April 26 this year. This proves that the video far precedes the November 10 terror attack in Delhi. We then reviewed the profile “mrbeast66” that shared the video on TikTok. On the account, we found several posts geotagged to United King, Karachi, a bakery shop in Karachi’s Badar Commercial Street. Additionally, the video of the train shared by “mrbeast66” includes hashtags like “pak fooj zindabad” and “pakistan zindabad”. Based on these details, it’s likely that this video is from Pakistan. That being said, we were unable to determine the exact location of the video, or where the train’s destination was. Notably, however, April 25 was right in the aftermath of the Pahalgam terror attack. India would go on to retaliate against Pakistan with Operation Sindoor in May. Thus, it is evident that while the video of the train carrying military tanks is likely from Pakistan, it predates the Delhi terror attack by several months — making the two things unrelated. (Written by Aryama Bhattacharjee)- EndsPublished By: Pathikrit SanyalPublished On: Nov 13, 2025Tune InMust Watch
label: fake

text: From Jamia to jail: Chancellor of terror-tainted Al-Falah has a shady past
cleaned_text: "Al-Falah" is Arabic for success, prosperity, and well-being. It was an apt name for a medical college in Faridabad. And then the November 10 Delhi blast happened. The Al-Falah School of Medical Sciences welcomed its debut batch of aspiring doctors just six years ago in 2019. Since then, it has turned into a sprawling campus, buzzing with students, teachers, and other staff. The founder of Al-Falah University (of which the medical college is a part) is Jawad Ahmad Siddiqui. A former lecturer, Siddiqui is now the director and founder of approximately a dozen ventures under the Al-Falah Group of Companies umbrella. Needless to say, he did well for himself. And the thousands of students studying at his university, especially the would-be doctors, thought they would too. But the explosion outside the Red Fort in New Delhi, which killed at least 12 people and injured many more, has not only thrust the Al-Falah Group into the spotlight for all the wrong reasons, but it has also tainted the reputation of the university beyond repair. And by extension, anyone involved with it. Jawad Ahmad Siddiqui. Had his university not been in the news for being the hub of the terrorists who allegedly executed the Delhi blast — and who were planning something much more sinister — chancellor and founder Jawad Ahmad Siddiqui would have been planning his birthday party at his plush mansion, called Al-Falah House, in Jamia Nagar. Sixty-one-year-old Jawad was born on November 15, 1964, as one of three sons to Hammad Ahmad Siddiqui. He grew up in Mhow, Madhya Pradesh, the birthplace of Bhimrao Ambedkar, after whom the town has now been renamed. According to his (non-active) LinkedIn profile, Jawad Ahmad Siddiqui completed BTech in Industrial and Product Design from Devi Ahilya Vishwavidyalaya in Indore. Later, his family moved to Delhi.Big dreams and shortcuts According to a former colleague who spoke to India Today Fact Check on the condition of anonymity, Jawad became a Mechanical Engineering lecturer at Jamia Millia Islamia in 1993. But his ambitions far exceeded the humble podium of a college. While working at Jamia, he dabbled in business and formed a few small companies with his brother Saood. Among these was Al-Falah Investments, which would eventually send them both to Tihar Jail for three years! Jamia to jail While at Jamia, Jawad persuaded some of his colleagues to invest in his business venture, promising hefty returns. However, he quickly became embroiled in a flurry of fraud, embezzlement, and cheating allegations. In 2000, a man called KR Singh lodged an FIR (No.43/2000) in Delhi’s New Friends Colony against Al Falah Investments Ltd. The case was investigated by the Economic Offence Wing of the Crime Branch in Delhi. Jawad was arrested and subsequently languished in jail for over three years with his brother. Rejecting his bail application in March 2003, the Delhi High Court noted that, in line with the allegations, the Forensic Science Laboratory in Delhi found that the “signatures of the investors were forged. The deposits were also received in the name of some of the companies which were non-existent. The petitioners diverted large funds received from the investors into their personal accounts and then misappropriated the same”. Jawad ultimately made bail in February 2004 and was later acquitted in the case by the Patiala Court in 2005, but only after he and his brother agreed to refund the investors they had defrauded.Faridabad college becomes ‘mini-Kashmir’ According to reliable sources, who did not want to be quoted, the Al-Falah School of Medical Sciences had a decent start back in 2019. But gradually, the college began hiring many doctors from Kashmir, primarily because they were cheap. Already a minority university, the environment on the campus became more and more orthodox following this. The management was apprised of the situation. It chose to ignore it. According to the same source, Dr Shaheen Saeed, who was arrested the day after the Delhi blast and has been linked to a terror module, was often seen persuading her colleagues and students into becoming more devout Muslims and wearing more conservative clothes like hijabs and burqas. In fact, she was even cautioned against such activities.More trouble at Al-Falah During the Covid-19 pandemic, nurses at Al-Falah alleged that they were fired when they demanded life insurance for working in a high-risk environment. Last year, medical interns were suspended when they protested the college’s poor infrastructure and the non-payment of stipends. Jawad may have been able to weather these storms. But the arrest of several doctors working at his medical college on terror charges has put his institution under the harshest of scanners, that of the NIA. Jawad’s birthday is just three days away. But the noose of a terror investigation is already tightening around him. The chancellor of Al-Falah may not be able to have a blast this year.- EndsPublished By: Pathikrit SanyalPublished On: Nov 12, 2025
label: fake

cleaned_text: Support fact checking and independent journalism Snopes IOS and Android App (unlimted articles, no ads, new Snopes crossword game) We know you count on Snopes to provide the unvarnished truth, and it's our highest priority to deliver facts without fear or favor. One of the defining characteristics of Snopes is our independence. While we currently rely on advertising revenue and traffic from search and social media platforms to sustain our operations, we are working to grow our membership base. By building that support, we will be able to rely less on external platforms and continue (and hopefully expand) Snopes' mission uninterrupted regardless of industry or tech changes. *By subscribing, you agree to our Terms & Conditions and Privacy Policy. text: Trump order prompts removal of report on missing and murdered Indigenous people from federal websites Written by: Laerke Christensen Dec. 4, 2025 DOJ said it removed the "Not One More" report from its website to comply with a Trump administra ... Read More
cleaned_text: About this rating The Department of Justice removed the report from its website but didn't outright call it "DEI content." Rather, a spokesperson told Snopes in an emailed statement the department removed the report following a Trump administration executive order on gender ideology, a concept that can fall under the wider diversity, equity and inclusion (DEI) umbrella in policy discussions. In November 2025, a claim (archived) circulated online that the administration of U.S. President Donald Trump removed a report on missing and murdered Native Americans, calling it "DEI content." One Facebook post on the topic read, "The Trump Administration has Removed the Report on Missing and Murdered Native Americans, Calling It DEI Content!" The claim also circulated on Instagram (archived), Threads (archived), Bluesky (archived) and Reddit (archived). Snopes readers wrote in to find out if the claim was true. The claim appeared to come from reporting by Oklahoma Watch, a nonprofit reporting project with a focus on public policy journalism. That outlet published an article on Nov. 14, 2025, titled, "Trump Administration Removes Report on Missing and Murdered Native Americans, Calling It DEI Content." According to that article, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) and the Interior (DOI) had removed a report, titled, "Not One More," that provided recommendations to the U.S. government on how to address a crisis of violence against Indigenous people who were "at a disproportionate risk of experiencing violence, murder, or going missing," according to the DOJ website. The report covered both men and women and used the abbreviation MMIP for "missing and murdered Indigenous people." A DOJ spokesperson said in an emailed statement to Snopes that the department removed the report "to ensure compliance with OPM [Office of Personnel Management] guidance regarding President Trump's Executive Order Defending Women." The statement said the report remained available on external websites. The DOJ did not outright call the report "DEI content" in its statement. The executive order in question that reportedly led to the report's removal discussed biological sex and gender ideology, which are concepts that can fall under the wider diversity, equity and inclusion (DEI) umbrella in policy discussions. Given the above, we have rated this claim as true. The report could not be accessed through the DOJ or DOI websites at the time of this writing. According to a DOI spokesperson, the department had linked to the report on its site but the link died when the DOJ removed the report from its website. We reached out to senators and representatives who campaigned to return the report to the DOJ and DOI websites to ask what they knew about the removal or whether the report might be restored. We await replies to our queries. According to the Internet Archive's Wayback Machine, a service that archives URLs, the "Not One More" report was last live at the link from the DOI website on Jan. 22, 2025. The Wayback Machine archived the link again on Feb. 2, 2025, where it led to a DOJ "Page not found" screen, meaning the DOJ removed the report sometime between Jan. 22 and Feb. 2, 2025. A spokesperson for the office of Democratic U.S. Sen. Catherine Cortez Masto of Nevada, who introduced the Not Invisible Act in the Senate in 2019 that formed the commission that published the "Not One More" report, said in an emailed statement that the office first discovered the report was missing on Feb. 8, 2025. Cortez Masto's office confirmed she and and Sen. Lisa Murkowski, a Republican senator from Alaska who chairs the Senate Indian Affairs Committee, wrote to the Trump administration to ask about restoring the "Not One More" report. The DOJ told Cortez Masto and Murkowski that the report "was removed in compliance with President Trump's Executive Order 'Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government,'" according to Cortez Masto's office, which echoed the DOJ statement that Snopes received. In July 2025, around five months after the "Not One More" report disappeared from the DOJ's website, a group of Democratic representatives led by U.S. Reps. Sharice Davids, D-KY, and Gwen Moore, D-WI, also wrote to U.S. Attorney General Pam Bondi, who heads the DOJ, to call for the department to restore the "Not One More" report on its website. Samara Sheff, Moore's press secretary, confirmed via email that the representatives did receive a response from the DOJ, but that Moore "is still focused on restoring the report" to the DOJ website. According to the reply that Sheff shared with Snopes, Theodore Schroeder, then-deputy assistant attorney general, wrote that the department removed the report in line with the Trump administration's executive order on gender ideology. Schroeder added that the department was "committed to addressing the issue of missing or murdered Indigenous people (MMIP)" and that the removal of the report "should not be misconstrued to indicate a change in this position or in our response to the recommendations issued by the Not Invisible Act Commission." Schroeder did not say in the response whether the DOJ would restore the report link. The DOJ did not reply to follow-up questions from Snopes about why it found the "Not One More" report was not in compliance with the Trump administration's executive order on gender ideology. In their July 2025 letter, Democratic representatives led by Davids and Moore argued that "the work done by the Not Invisible Act Commission explicitly does not promote gender ideology or extremism." The representatives wrote, "Though there is mention within the findings themselves that women compose a large percentage of MMIP individuals, there ceases to be a link between gender extremism and ideology and the work of the Not Invisible Commission." "Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government" was a sweeping executive order that laid out a new U.S. policy "to recognize two sexes, male and female." Part of this policy read: (e) Agencies shall remove all statements, policies, regulations, forms, communications, or other internal and external messages that promote or otherwise inculcate gender ideology, and shall cease issuing such statements, policies, regulations, forms, communications or other messages. Agency forms that require an individual's sex shall list male or female, and shall not request gender identity. Agencies shall take all necessary steps, as permitted by law, to end the Federal funding of gender ideology. This subsection was the only part of the order that referred to government agencies removing content. It remained unclear at the time of this writing why the DOJ concluded the "Not One More" report promoted or otherwise inculcated gender ideology. The department had not restored the report to its website at the time of this writing, nor did it appear it intended to. Davids, Moore, Colleagues Push to Restore Report on MMIP Crisis | Representative Sharice Davids. 14 July 2025, http://davids.house.gov/media/press-releases/davids-moore-colleagues-push-restore-report-mmip-crisis. "Defending Women From Gender Ideology Extremism And Restoring Biological Truth To The Federal Government." The White House, 21 Jan. 2025, https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/01/defending-women-from-gender-ideology-extremism-and-restoring-biological-truth-to-the-federal-government/. Luetkemeyer, Em. "Trump Administration Removes Report on Missing and Murdered Native Americans, Calling It DEI Content." Oklahoma Watch, 14 Nov. 2025, https://oklahomawatch.org/2025/11/14/trump-administration-removes-report-on-missing-and-murdered-native-americans-calling-it-dei-content/. Moore, Gwen S., et al. Dear Attorney General Bondi,. 9 July 2025, https://gwenmoore.house.gov/uploadedfiles/final_not_invisible_act_letter.pdf. Not Invisible Act Commission | U.S. Department of the Interior. Site page. 5 May 2022, https://www.doi.gov/priorities/strengthening-indian-country/not-invisible-act-commission. "NOT ONE MORE." THE NOT INVISIBLE ACT COMMISSION, 1 Nov. 2023, https://www.niwrc.org/sites/default/files/files/34%20NIAC%20Final%20Report_version%2011.1.23_FINAL_0.pdf. "Page Not Found." Congress.gov, Library of Congress, 10 October 2020, https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/senate-bill/982. Laerke Christensen is a journalist based in London, England, with expertise in OSINT reporting. Company Navigate Sections Account © 1995 - 2025 by Snopes, Inc. text: Did Kristi Noem genuinely thank Trump for keeping hurricanes away? Written by: Jordan Liles Dec. 3, 2025 The homeland security secretary made the remark during a White House Cabinet meeting on Dec. 2, ... Read More
cleaned_text: About this rating During a publicly broadcast Cabinet meeting Dec. 2, 2025, Noem truly said, "Sir, you made it through hurricane season without a hurricane. And so, FEMA, FEMA … you, even you kept the hurricanes away, so we appreciate that." However, audible laughter as well as Noem then continuing her FEMA comment showed the room received the "you kept the hurricanes away" remark as nothing more than an off-the-cuff joke. A rumor that circulated online in early December 2025 claimed U.S. Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem thanked President Donald Trump for keeping hurricanes away from the country through the 2025 hurricane season, following a remark Noem made during a publicly broadcast White House Cabinet meeting on Dec. 2. For example, on Dec. 2, the progressive Occupy Democrats Facebook page posted (archived) an image displaying photos of Noem and Trump. The post's caption read in part, "Kristi Noem goes full North Korea and thanks Dear Leader for…keeping hurricanes away?" (Occupy Democrats/Facebook) That post featured a comment from a page manager with a link to video (archived) of Noem's alleged remark. The post's caption continued, in part, as follows: During today's obedience-displaying and shameless a**-kissing convention that the Trump team calls a "cabinet meeting," Department of Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem thanked Trump for keeping hurricanes away. Yes, keeping hurricanes away. "Sir, you made it through hurricane season without a hurricane. And so FEMA — you even kept the hurricanes away! — And FEMA is deploying resources and dollars 150% faster than ever before. So somebody does have something bad that happens to them, you are immediately there helping them and telling them they have the resources to get back up on their feet." Clearly, Trump simply took his big black marker and drew arrows telling the hurricanes to go somewhere else! Masterfully done, Mr. President! Publishers and users also shared the claim on Bluesky, Facebook (archived), Instagram (archived), Threads (archived), TikTok (archived), X (archived) and YouTube. In short, the quote was correctly attributed to Noem, who made the remark as an off-the-cuff joke. As the video showed, Noem truly said to Trump, "Sir, you made it through hurricane season without a hurricane. And so, FEMA, FEMA … you, even you kept the hurricanes away, so we appreciate that." Noem then continued with her remark about the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which she previously attempted to begin speaking about. Laughs audible in videos from the meeting — as well as the continuation of her FEMA comment — showed the room received Noem's "you kept the hurricanes away" remark as nothing more than ad-libbed humor. Snopes contacted DHS and the White House by email to ask about users' claims, including the many posts that did not mention the laughs and the fact that the room received the comment as a joke. We will update this story if we receive further information. The moment in which Noem mentions hurricanes occurs at the 1:24:00 mark in the official White House YouTube channel's video of the Cabinet meeting: The CNBC YouTube channel also features a video showing Trump's reaction to the same comments, beginning at the 1:24:05 mark: USA Today reported no hurricanes made landfall in the U.S. in 2025. In other significant weather events occurring during the year, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration reported the remnants of Tropical Storm Barry, along with other elements, combined to form rainfall that resulted in the July flash floods that killed more than 135 people in Texas, including children and adults at summer camps. Also in July, at least six people died in North Caroline as a result of flooding from the remnants of Tropic Storm Chantal. For further reading, we previously reported about other rumors coming out of the same meeting, including the widespread claims that videos showed Trump falling asleep, and that the name card for Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth displayed the misspelled title "Ssecretary of War." Borresen, Jennifer. "Why the 2025 Atlantic Hurricane Season Was Unlike Any in the Past Decade." USA TODAY, 29 Nov. 2025, https://www.usatoday.com/story/graphics/2025/11/29/2025-hurricane-season-ends/87128985007/. Danielle, Monica. Flash Flooding Kills 6 in North Carolina after Days of Heavy Rain. AccuWeather. 11 July 2025, https://www.accuweather.com/en/hurricane/8-dead-in-north-carolina-after-tropical-storm-chantal/1793741. Hoell, Andrew, et al. "Weather Whiplash in Texas: Drought to Flood." National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Physical Sciences Laboratory, 11 Aug. 2025. "President Trump Holds a Cabinet Meeting at the White House — 12/2/2025." YouTube, CNBC Television, 2 Dec. 2025, https://www.youtube.com/live/sam5neuduko. "President Trump Hosts a Cabinet Meeting, Dec. 2, 2025." YouTube, The White House, 2 Dec. 2025, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pZSd7jn9CSc. Sharif, Hatim. "Why Texas Hill Country, Where a Devastating Flood Killed More than 135 People, Is One of the Deadliest Places in the US for Flash Flooding." text: Did Megyn Kelly say she wanted to see survivors of strike on alleged drug boat 'suffer'? Written by: Emery Winter Dec. 3, 2025 The Department of Defense reportedly killed two survivors of a strike on an alleged drug boat in ... Read More
cleaned_text: About this rating Kelly prefaced her defense of the strikes by saying that "the armed forces should not commit war crimes." In December 2025, social media users widely shared a clip of Megyn Kelly, a former Fox News host, talking on a podcast about a reported strike by the U.S. military on an alleged drug boat. One post on X (archived) said: Megyn Kelly on alleged war crimes: "I really do kind of not only wanna see them killed in the water, whether they're on the boat or in the water, but I'd really like to see them suffer. I would like [President Donald] Trump and [Defense Secretary Pete] Hegseth to make it last a long time so they lose a limb and bleed out." The comment appeared to be in response to recent scrutiny of Hegseth over a report that the military carried out a likely illegal follow-up strike to kill survivors of an initial attack in the Caribbean. Users also shared the quote on Instagram (archived), Reddit (archived) and Bluesky (archived). The quote about seeing "them killed in the water" and suffering was correctly attributed to Kelly, who was commenting on reports that the Department of Defense carried out a follow-up strike on survivors of an initial strike on an alleged drug boat. Kelly discussed the reported strike on the Dec. 1, 2025, episode of her podcast "The Megyn Kelly Show." The quote widely shared across social media came at about 37:17 in the YouTube video of the episode, as she spoke with commentator Mark Halperin. The full context of Kelly's quote, including the commentary on scrutiny around the strikes that the quote was a part of, was as followed (emphasis ours): In any event, it's like to me it's kind of annoying to even debate it. I do think our soldiers and, you know, all armed forces should not commit war crimes. Definitely on team, don't commit a war crime. But I also feel like I object to even the scrutiny of this event because it's all manufactured. It's only being done to retroactively justify this, you know, Seditious Six and their — that's what Hegseth is calling them — and their video which was based on nothing. They're just now digging. It's a fishing expedition and it does feel a little, you know, Stalin's right-hand man-eqsue like, "Show me the man and I'll show you the crime." That's how it feels to me, so I'm really not that into it, nor do I really care that we're killing the drug boat guys trying to kill my kids and yours right now by bringing their fentanyl to the United States to try to get our kids when they go to college with, you know, some drug in some moment of weakness where they think they're taking a Xanax like what happened to poor Eric Bowling's child, and instead it's laced with fentanyl. So, I really do kind of not only want to see them killed in the water, whether they're on the boat or in the water, but I'd really like to see them suffer. I would like Trump and Hegseth to make it last a long time so that they lose a limb and bleed out a little — like I'm really having a difficult time ginning up sympathy for these guys who 10 seconds earlier almost got taken out by the initial bomb, but because they managed to get ejected, you know, a little too soon had to be taken out in the water. I realize legally it may make a difference, but truly, Mark, this is a tough case to really gin up the sympathies of the American people. Since September 2025, the Trump administration has carried out a number of strikes in South American waters of the Caribbean Sea against what it has alleged are drug-trafficking boats. In late November, The Washington Post reported that Hegseth gave the order to "kill everybody" on a boat the military targeted in the strike in question in September. Once it became evident that two people had survived the initial strike, the commander of the operation "ordered a second strike to comply with Hegseth's instructions," according to the Post. Since then, Hegseth has acknowledged that U.S. armed forces carried out a follow-up strike on survivors of that initial strike, claiming it occurred due to the "fog of war." Members of Congress have scrutinized Hegseth and his role in the reported strikes. The Associated Press reported that several legal experts "believed the second strike violated peacetime laws and those governing armed conflict." It also reported that the Department of Defense's manual on the laws of armed conflict specifically cites striking survivors of a sunken ship as being illegal. Under a subsection on the duty of individual members of the armed forces to refuse to comply with "clearly illegal orders" to commit war crimes, the manual at the time of the strikes said (Page 1088, emphasis ours): "The requirement to refuse to comply with orders to commit law of war violations applies to orders to perform conduct that is clearly illegal or orders that the subordinate knows, in fact, are illegal. For example, orders to fire upon the shipwrecked would be clearly illegal." Finley, Ben, et al. "Welcome to Zscaler Directory Authentication." AP News, 17 Nov. 2025, apnews.com/article/trump-boat-strikes-caribbean-military-venezuela-timeline-2dd9d16f4f74d9dfa4aca76d3123678d. Accessed 3 Dec. 2025. Groves, Stephen, and Lisa Mascaro. "Hegseth Is Scrutinized by Congress over Boat Strikes." AP News, 3 Dec. 2025, apnews.com/article/congress-hegseth-boat-strikes-e68621ec48c7886215359c0110d6d9ca. Accessed 3 Dec. 2025. Horton, Alex, and Ellen Nakashima. "Hegseth Order on First Caribbean Boat Strike, Officials Say: Kill Them All." The Washington Post, 28 Nov. 2025, www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/2025/11/28/hegseth-kill-them-all-survivors-boat-strike/. Accessed 3 Dec. 2025. Konstantin Toropin. "Hegseth Cites "Fog of War" in Defending Follow-on Boat Strike." AP News, 2 Dec. 2025, apnews.com/article/hegseth-trump-venezuela-540ae279827e02105e089f1bd5af37a6. Accessed 3 Dec. 2025. Megyn Kelly. "Real Story behind Hegseth "Double Tap" Reporting, and Katie Miller vs Abby Phillip, W/ Mark Halperin." YouTube, 1 Dec. 2025, www.youtube.com/watch?v=7twXeevx5y8. Accessed 3 Dec. 2025. Emery Winter is based in Charlotte, North Carolina, and previously worked for TEGNA'S VERIFY national fact-checking team. They enjoy sports and video games. text: Do videos show Trump falling asleep during Cabinet meeting? Written by: Jordan Liles Dec. 3, 2025 Users shared videos alleging to show President Trump dozing off and falling asleep during a leng ... Read More
cleaned_text: About this rating A rumor that circulated online in early December 2025 claimed a handful of videos showed U.S. President Donald Trump falling asleep at various moments during a White House Cabinet meeting. That meeting, with the video-recorded portion lasting over two hours, took place on Dec. 2. For example, one X user's post (archived) featured a brief clip of Secretary of State Marco Rubio speaking during the meeting, seated directly next to Trump's right side. The video, also posted on Reddit (archived), showed Trump opening and fully closing his eyes, and displayed the caption, "Trump dozes while Marco Rubio speaks to him directly next to him. Just insane optics." Other users claimed of the same moment that Trump "fell asleep," or used the term "doze off." The New York Times shared a video on Bluesky, Facebook and TikTok (archived) from a different moment, showing Trump's eyes opening and slowly closing in a repeated manner — including him nodding to acknowledge remarks — during comments delivered by Secretary of Agriculture Brooke Rollins. The Times reported Trump "appeared to be fighting sleep" while "seeming to nod off." Users reposted another video (archived) highlighting numerous moments in which Trump completely closed his eyes. The first part of the poor-quality clip, featuring Secretary of Labor Lori Chavez-DeRemer speaking about "Main Street," showed Trump's head slightly dropping in the same manner as when a person begins nodding off. The CNBC YouTube channel hosted a higher-quality video of the same moment, occurring from the 1:15:20 to 1:15:30 marks. In short, users' videos truly showed a sleepy Trump during the Cabinet meeting and did not merely show him closing his eyes for quiet reflection or other purposes — as evidenced by the above clips as well as additional footage of him twice yawning (1:34:21-1:34:29) and beginning to fall asleep, including with his head dropping and subsequently coming back up (1:16:07-1:16:30). During the meeting, the drowsy president remained alert to acknowledge speakers' statements, as well as to call on each prominent person seated in the room. Snopes contacted the White House via email and asked if Trump repeatedly dozed off during the meeting, as well as if it had a statement to share about this matter. In response, White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt did not answer the specific question of whether Trump repeatedly dozed off. Leavitt told us, in part, "President Trump was listening attentively and running the entire three-hour marathon Cabinet meeting." The video-recorded portion of the meeting lasted around 2 hours and 18 minutes, not three hours. It's unclear if she was referencing a private part of a Cabinet meeting occurring prior to the video-recorded portion. Her full statement read as follows: President Trump was listening attentively and running the entire three-hour marathon Cabinet meeting. Just go back and watch his amazing final answer in the press conference, where he ripped into the America-Last Democrats for allowing radical Somali migrants to invade our country and steal from American taxpayers. This epic moment put an exclamation point on President Trump's ninth Cabinet meeting of his second term—all of which have been entirely open to the press for the whole world to see. In all of these historic meetings, the President and his incredible team highlight the exhaustive list of accomplishments they have delivered on behalf of the American people to Make America Great Again. The CNBC YouTube video, with the camera remaining on Trump the entire time, depicted him opening the meeting by speaking for 32 minutes. Toward the middle of the clip, his appearance and posture displayed signs of him becoming drowsy. That drowsiness continued until he continued speaking to wrap up the meeting. At the 1:15:38 mark in the video, Trump wipes his left eye with his left hand, then positions his fingers against his left temple, as captured in photos hosted on the Getty Images website, as well as above this article. The aforementioned additional moment showing him beginning to fall asleep, with his head dropping and then coming back up, occurs around 30-60 seconds later between 1:16:07-1:16:30. Numerous professionally captured still photos also showed Trump's eyes partially or fully closed at various moments during the meeting. While photographers possibly captured those pictures during moments of blinking or momentary eye-closing, the fact remained that videos depicted a drowsy Trump yawning and numerous times slowly dropping his head to begin falling asleep. For further reading, we previously reported about other times users falsely, or without presenting credible evidence, alleged videos showed Trump falling asleep, including while attending Pope Francis' funeral service and during the 2024 Republican National Convention. We also dispelled similar claims regarding videos purportedly depicting former President Joe Biden as dozing off. Kanno-Youngs, Zolan. "Trump Appears to Fight Sleep During Cabinet Meeting." text: Pete Hegseth's title was misspelled as 'Ssecretary of War' on nameplate Written by: Nur Ibrahim Dec. 3, 2025 The nameplate was used during President Donald Trump's final White House Cabinet meeting of 2025. Read More
cleaned_text: About this rating On Dec. 2, 2025, during the final White House Cabinet meeting of the year, eagle-eyed viewers noticed what appeared to be a curious spelling error on one of the placards. According to images and screenshots shared of the meeting, U.S. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth's title was misspelled on his placard, reading "Ssecretary of War." Snopes readers shared an image of Hegseth seated behind the apparently misspelt placard and asked us to ascertain whether the error was real. Some readers even suggested the "SS" was "giving Nazi." California Democratic Gov. Gavin Newsom's press office shared what appeared to be a screenshot from a video of Hegseth speaking with his name card in front of him revealing the apparent spelling error. The office posted the image with the caption: "What does the 'SS' stand for? Interesting!" The misspelling was indeed real. We found the error in the footage of the meeting posted by the White House, as well as in photographs published on Getty Images by various photojournalists covering the event. As such, we rate this claim true. The "SS" evoking the Nazi Schutzstaffel paramilitary organization in Germany during World War II was likely unintentional. Whatever the reason for the spelling error, other members of the Cabinet did not have such misspellings on their placards. We reached out to the White House to learn more and will update this story if we get more information. We looked closely at the White House's YouTube video of the entire Cabinet meeting on Dec. 2. Hegseth's placard is visible at various points during his remarks, and can be seen at the 33:24 mark and after the 35:00 mark when the camera zooms out. Close-up photographs taken by Agence France-Presse photographer Andrew Caballero-Reynolds and Getty Images photographer Chip Somodevilla showed the misspelling more clearly. The AFP photograph caption states: The word Secretary is misspelled on the nameplate of US Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth during a Cabinet Meeting hosted by President Donald Trump in the Cabinet Room of the White House in Washington, DC on December 2, 2025. (Andrew Caballero-Reynolds/AFP/Getty Images) (Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images) Hegseth was defending the September 2025 U.S. follow-up missile strike on an alleged drug boat in the Caribbean Sea, which reportedly had shipwrecked survivors. During the Cabinet meeting, Hegseth said he did not watch the entire operation or "personally see survivors" but said a second strike that sank the boat was "the right call" and part of the "fog of war." Trump issued an executive order in September 2025 to rebrand the Department of Defense as the Department of War, though legally renaming it requires an act of Congress. We have reported on numerous claims about Hegseth, including the rumor he authored a memo canceling the military's support of Scouting America because the Scouts no longer promoted "masculine values" and the satirical claim that he poked his own eye with a mascara brush.
